webTitle: Piper Alpha survivors recall disaster 25 years on

fields.standfirst: Charles Haffey remembers the terror on board the North Sea oil rig when it exploded on the night of 6 July 1988
fields.body:
Even 25 years on, Charles Haffey's most powerful memory of the Piper Alpha disaster was the overwhelming, deafening noise. The vast inferno created by simultaneous eruptions from ruptured gas and crude oil pipelines sounded like thousands of blow torches alight at full pressure.

That intense, inescapable roar was accompanied by other sounds, as the extraordinary heat melted steel, fracturing Piper Alpha's vast structure, as glass windows exploded and as its offices, canteens and sleeping quarters disintegrated.

There were three then four vast explosions, each seeming more devastating than the last, spread out over several hours.

"At the time we felt detached from what was going on because I suppose psychologically your brain can't process what's going on. It was surreal. Your mind can't take it in," Haffey said, in an interview with the Guardian.

"If you take the actual rig itself, the best way you can describe the rig is if you can imagine a welder's blow torch and magnify it thousands of times. The brain switches off; your brain can't accept what's happening. At the back of your mind you're aware that the next step you take could be your last. You have no sense of time."

He remembers the heat: on one effort to find survivors who had jumped into the sea – dozens of men jumped, some from 180 feet or more - they had sailed under Piper Alpha, some 20 to 30 feet from the burning platform.

They were saved from being boiled by the overwhelming heat by water being hosed over their heads from the Tharos, Piper Alpha's semi-submersible fire-fighting and accommodation vessel. "I remember going through this thin mist: somebody on the Tharos had turned the water on to keep us cool," he said. "We managed to get through it and picked these guys up."

Haffey, now a civil servant living in Fife, was on board Piper Alpha's rescue vessel, the Silver Pit, when the rig exploded on the night of 6 July 1988. As one of the men most heavily involved in the rescue effort. He had both a grandstand seat and a hands' on role in the disaster.

He recalled hearing the staccato detonations of explosions, the sounds of men screaming, of retrieving burnt survivors and bodies, and once watching one man drown. Two fellow crew men on the Silver Pit were killed too, on a Zodiac fast rescue boat.

He had had previous experience of violence at sea: Haffey had served in the Falklands war in 1982, as a sonar operator on board HMS Yarmouth, a Type 12 frigate which was heavily involved in the fighting before and after the Royal Marines landed in San Carlos Water.

In his interview for a new documentary on the disaster, Fire in the Night, based on a book of the same name by the journalist Stephen McGinty, Haffey said: "If you're working in a factory, your alarm bell goes, you go into the car park, you are safe, yeah? You get your name ticked off, the fire brigade arrives, yeah? That doesn't happen at sea, particularly not on a ship, particularly not on an oil rig, yeah?

"That fire alarm goes off, if you can't fight that fire, if something happens to you rig, or happens to that ship and you end up in the water, that's when your survival starts. That's the beginning of your problems, it's not the end of your problems, it's the beginning of your problems."

Remarkably, two weeks after Piper Alpha, Haffey was back at sea after resuming his role on board the Silver Pit. It was back on site as a guard vessel. He saw the shattered remains of the platform being sunk into the sea in a muted ceremony to clear the site.

He recalled on Fire in the Night his conflicted feelings. "It kind of reminded me of a squat, ugly crab, you know? [And] you hated this thing, you hated this thing, because it caused so much misery. You didn't want it to be there – you wanted it wiped from the face of the Earth. And yet I was also there when they brought the Piper Alpha down, when they demolished it.

"[Then] I remember thinking 'But there's nothing there any more'. I hated it for being there but when they demolished it, you hated it for not being there, because there was nothing there that said something terrible, something … a great tragedy's happened here."

For many, many other men who survived Piper Alpha, the psychological trauma was intense and far-reaching.

A study published in the British Journal of Psychology by three experts in disasters then based at the Centre for Trauma Research at Royal Cornhill hospital in Aberdeen, Alastair Hull, David Alexander and Susan Klein in 2002 found that significant rates of survivor guilt, anger, acute post traumatic stress and physical injury. Nearly every survivor experienced psychological trauma.

They interviewed 36 survivors: a third of those experienced survivor guilt 10 years after the disaster, and 70% acute guilt. Another 61% had "performance guilt", blaming themselves for their decisions on the night. Nearly every man there lost a friend and 86% saw someone killed or severely injured.

Hull, now with NHS Tayside, said there was one other significant but so far unreported finding as the disaster worsened: very high levels of "collegiate behaviour", or selfless cooperation and comradeliness with men they barely knew.

"We found a huge number of very collegiate descriptions: of men deciding to help others who they didn't necessarily know terribly well, and coming together almost as teams to help each other survive. Quite startling examples," Hull told the Guardian.

"A very high percentage of people thought that they were going to die," he said. "Some of the men had very prolonged escapes." Unlike many disasters which occur suddenly and quickly, the Piper Alpha disaster was drawn out: it was several hours before the final devastating explosions.

Yet the trapped men repeatedly showed altruism was not restricted to friends or workmates. "It was one man's first ever shift on Piper Alpha," Hull said. "It was very very clear they helped whoever was there."

Haffey said his response to the disaster at the time was not to dwell on it – he felt "there was no point for me either regretting it or not regretting it". But he confirms there were some mental scars: anger was one significant after effect. But he no longer feels any anger.

"I'm fed up feeling angry, because no matter how angry you are, you're not going to change anything that night. I was angry, I would say, for about the first ten years but somehow you just have to reason with yourself: no matter how angry you get about this you're not going to bring those guys back."

webTitle: Five ways Australians are spending money

fields.standfirst: As department stores continue to struggle, the big winners in the past five years have been cafes and restaurants
fields.body:
1. Holding an election is unlikely to make consumers spend more

On Wednesday, the May Retail Sales figures were released showing a mere 0.1% increase in sales. This came off the back of a number of business groups bleating about how the uncertainty of an election date was bad for confidence and the economy.

While it must be annoying for some that our democracy gets in the way of their profits, business CEOs had better start finding other reasons for why they are not doing as well as they expected. Elections don’t really seem to faze consumers. In the 11 elections since 1983, seven times the growth in retail sales has been better in the six months before the election than the six months after.

It’s even worse if we look at consumer confidence. In the 14 federal elections since 1975, according to the Westpac-Melbourne Institute Index, only three times has consumer confidence grown more in the six months after an election than the six months beforehand (1975, 1998, and 2001).

The reality is people for the most part keep calm and carry on shopping. Only in very specific areas does the election directly matter – selling a house in Canberra at the moment might be a tough ask given concerns about public service cutbacks, but even there the growth of home loans is not that different to the rest of Australia

It seems Australians are pretty well at ease with the whole democracy thing.

2. We still like cars, but not the cars our parents liked

In May, for the first time ever, sales of passenger vehicles made up less than 50% of all motor vehicles:

The fall in passenger cars has been due to our new love for Sports Utility Vehicles (SUVs). Ten years ago SUVs made up only 16% of the total market; now it is 30%. Total sales of cars actually achieved a record level at the end of 2012, but not for passenger cars. The problem, of course, is that while sales of cars is a good indicator of economic health, the only locally made SUV is the Ford Territory that means the boom segment of the market isn’t helping car production in our local industry.

Holden recently announced it wouldn’t bother making an SUV because it wouldn’t be likely to sell enough to make it worth its while. 

That’s the local car industry problem in a nutshell – the only type of cars that sells enough to warrant being produced here are passenger cars, but it is the one segment of the market that is shrinking.

3. For once we’re fixing our home loans when the rates are low

In April, the percentage of home loans taken that were fixed went above 20%. To an extent this isn’t surprising. With interest rates at record lows, it is logical that many people are locking in those rates for a few years. Logical but unusual:

In the past, the number of fixed rate mortgages increased when interest rates increased. This sounds sensible – it involves trying to fix in a rate when you think rates will keep going up. But it sees a rate being fixed at the top rather than at the bottom. In March 2008 a quarter home loans taken out were fixed when rates had been rising, but when the GFC hit things went south quick smart. Within 12 months the standard variable home loan rate fell from 9.35% to 5.85%. And that was good time to have a variable home loan.

4. We’re still shopping but not stupidly

For the past two and a half years annual growth in retail sales has been around 3%.

That is the longest period we’ve gone in the past 15 years with such low growth and it shows how different the economy is than prior to the GFC.

For much of the time from 1998 to 2008 a strong economy meant fairly massive spending. Thus we saw big spending invariably followed by periods where we suffered shopping indigestion, before we headed back to the shops again in big numbers.

Since 2010 we have largely stayed calm. Our spending is growing, but not absurdly. Sure Gerry Harvey might not like this as much, but it seems to me to be much more stable.

5. We're eating out more than we used to

Just as we have changed our choice of car, so too do we now shop differently. Twenty years ago we did about 22% of our non-food type shopping in department stores; now only 15% of such shopping is done there. We’ve left Myer and David Jones and headed to JB Hi Fi and Harvey Norman. During the boom retail period of 2000 to 2005 spending in “Household Goods Retailers” grew by around 50%. In contrast spending in department stores grew by only 30% (the worst of all categories).

In the past five years, department stores have continued to struggle. We actually spent more in such stores in May 2008 than we did in May 2013. However in the past five years, Harvey Norman and other household, electrical and hardware stores have also struggled. So what is the big winner of the past five years? 

Restaurants, cafes and takeaways.

If the period before the GFC was about spending money to spruce up your house or fill it with as many big screen TVs as you had walls, then the past five years have been about spending your disposable income eating out, and (if like me) drinking many, many coffees.

webTitle: Tony Buckingham: I wouldn't bend evidence to help a mate

fields.standfirst: Tribunal hears Heritage Oil founder testify at hearing in which City dealmaker friend Ian Hannam fights market abuse fine
fields.body:
Tony Buckingham, the buccaneering multimillionaire oilman, told a tribunal he would not bend his evidence to protect his "great mate" Ian Hannam, the City of London dealmaker who is fighting a £450,000 market abuse fine.

Buckingham, founder and chief executive of Heritage Oil, took the stand on the third day of the hearing. Hannam is accused of passing on insider information.

The case mounted by the Financial Conduct Authority, formerly the Financial Services Authority, turns on two 2008 emails that Hannam sent about Heritage Oil, his longstanding client, to Ashti Hawrami, the oil minister of the Kurdistan Regional Government in northern Iraq, who was a potential client of Hannam and investor in Heritage.

One email said that Heritage had made an oil discovery that was "looking good" – several weeks before this market sensitive information was publicly released. The FCA states it would have been clear from public information that the email related to Heritage's Warthog-1 well in Uganda.

Asked whether he knew Hannam was sharing information, Buckingham said: "Absolutely not."

The FCA's counsel said Buckingham's "first instinctive reaction" was surprise when confronted with that October email by the FSA at an interview five years ago, whereas in the tribunal his "generally honest evidence" was tinged with "a degree of rationalisation".

Buckingham said he would not bend the evidence to help his old friend. "Although he is a great mate and I think the world of him, would I go out of my way to manipulate the evidence? Absolutely not.

"I felt there was an implicit understanding between the parties and the implicit understanding was that everyone was aware of what sensitive information was," he said.

Buckingham said that the postscript – "Tony has just found oil and it is looking good" – was wrong. "The reference to 'we have found oil' was clearly wrong. I certainly would not have been in a position to say definitively 'we've found oil'."

As well as Buckingham's assessment of Hawrami, whom he described as "a very competent wily old fox", the tribunal also shed light on deal-making in the oil world. Buckingham recounted his fury when the privately owned French oil company Perenco made a £400m offer for Heritage – less than half what he had hoped for.

"It was a beautiful sunny day and I was walking in Verviers in the mountains," he told the tribunal of the moment when the ill-fated phonecall came through. "I can't remember the exact expletive I used but I was none too pleased." The talks had been "a complete waste of everybody's time" and "a fishing exercise," he said.

In his testimony, Hannam told the tribunal he had not passed on insider information and said some of his words were being taken out of context by the FCA counsel.

The hearing continues.

webTitle: City shirtmaker TM Lewin up for sale

fields.standfirst: Chain to be sold by Coller Capital just over a year after refinancing, but chief executive Geoff Quinn likely to stay at helm
fields.body:
TM Lewin, the shirtmaker chain, has been put up for sale by Coller Capital, a distressed investment specialist, just over a year after it underwent a painful refinancing. It has appointed corporate financiers from KMPG to find a buyer, with Geoff Quinn, the autodidact chief executive who led a troubled management buyout in 2006, thought likely to remain at the helm.

Quinn, 54, left school with one O-level, in pottery, and has been at TM Lewin since it was a single store on London's Jermyn Street. The business now has about 90 shops in the UK as well as operations overseas. It has had a shop on London's Jermyn Street since 1898, where, it claims, its founder, Thomas Mayes Lewin, introduced the first shirts buttoned all the way down the front – the "shirt coat".

TM Lewin is the latest in a basket of troubled private equity buyouts put up for sale by Coller after it acquired a majority interest in the investments from taxpayer-backed Lloyds Banking Group last summer in a £480m deal. The portfolio of buyouts, mostly dating from 2006 and 2007, is a legacy of Peter Cummings' controversial corporate banking division at Bank of Scotland, now part of Lloyds.

In April, Coller sold D&D, the upmarket restaurant group behind London eateries Coq D'Argent, Skylon and Bluebird, to another private equity house, LDC, in a £50m management buyout. Also reportedly up for sale is the struggling gym and tennis club group David Lloyd Leisure, backed by Coller in conjunction with property barons Ian and Richard Livingstone. Any disposal is expected to be accompanied by a refinancing.

TM Lewin was refinanced in April last year, with Quinn later claiming the revised arrangements had put its borrowings on "more sensible terms", with repayment deadlines for the bulk of its £33.5m bank loans pushed out to between two and five years. The latest accounts show that for the year to March 2012, the firm posted top-line operating profits of £12m, down 18%, despite sales up 6% to £106m.

When the basket of private equity deals was sold by Lloyds into a joint venture with Coller Capital, founded by Jeremy Coller, the taxpayer-backed bank retained a 30% interest in the venture, known as Cavendish Square Partners. In January the Guardian reported that an advisory business which manages Cavendish Square on behalf of Coller and Lloyds had received £12m for its work for the year to March 2012. The advisory firm, called Caird Capital, was set up by Graeme Shankland, a former Bank of Scotland senior executive whose division at the bank had invested in the ill-fated buyouts. Shankland and his partners at Caird are expected to do well if disposals of David Lloyd Leisure and TM Lewin go well.

Bank of Scotland's corporate division was heavily criticised by the Financial Services Authority in two reports last year. The regulator, which has since been renamed the Financial Conduct Authority, found a "culture of optimism" at the Bank in assessing credit risk had contributed to "a collective denial".

Last September Shankland's onetime boss at BoS, Peter Cummings, was given a lifetime ban from the banking industry by the Financial Services Authority and was fined £500,000.

Also among the assets in the Cavendish Square Partners joint venture, are Keepmoat, the regeneration and public housing firm.

When the basket of private equity deals was sold by Lloyds into a joint venture with Coller Capital, founded by Jeremy Coller, the taxpayer-backed bank retained a 30% interest in the venture, known as Cavendish Square Partners. In January the Guardian reported that an advisory business which manages Cavendish Square on behalf of Coller and Lloyds had received £12m for its work for the year to March 2012. The advisory firm, called Caird Capital, was set up by Graeme Shankland, a former Bank of Scotland senior executive whose division at the bank had invested in the ill-fated buyouts. Shankland and his partners at Caird are expected to do well if disposals of David Lloyd Leisure and TM Lewin go well. Bank of Scotland's corporate division was heavily criticised by the Financial Services Authority in two reports last year. The regulator, which has since been renamed the Financial Conduct Authority, found a "culture of optimism" at the Bank in assessing credit risk had contributed to "a collective denial". Last September Shankland's onetime boss at BoS, Peter Cummings, was given a lifetime ban from the banking industry by the Financial Services Authority and was fined £500,000. Also among the assets in the Cavendish Square Partners joint venture, are Keepmoat, the regeneration and public housing firm.
fields.headline: City shirtmaker TM Lewin up for sale
fields.trailText: Chain to be sold by Coller Capital just over a year after refinancing, but chief executive Geoff Quinn likely to stay at helm

webTitle: €500,000 bankers' bonus cap 'could increase risk'

fields.standfirst: Deutsche Bank's Steven Ward says more risk might enter system because of difficulty in retaining or attracting top talent
fields.body:
Banks have warned the European Union that plans to cap bonuses exceeding €500,000 (£428,000) would drive talent away and would not accurately identify risk takers. The European Banking Authority fielded questions from banks at a public hearing on how it intended to identify individuals who raised an institution's risk profile.

EBA definitions of risk takers include those whose "total remuneration exceeds, in absolute terms, €500,000 per year". The EBA is expected to make recommendations to the EU after a consultation period ends on 21 August.

Attending a public hearing on the consultation paper, Steven Ward of Deutsche Bank said that talented people would be put off working in European banking. "Given that we will not have globally a level playing field, our ability internationally, particularly in the US and Asia, to attract and retain key control function staff particularly in risk management is impacted by where that threshold is set.

"So I worry that we could introduce more risk into the system by not being able to retain or attract the right quality of people outside Europe."

Andrew Trapnell, chairman of the Association for Financial Markets in Europe's remuneration working group, warned the proposals might lead to other unintended consequences. He said that some individuals in financial institutions might earn above the threshold without being material risk takers.

"For example in some institutions there are research functions, maybe economic analysts. They may be paid significant amounts of money usually because they are followed in the market but their earnings potential is fee based for the organisation. There is no risk attached to the type of role that they do," he said.

The EBA said it was willing to have a debate about thresholds but suggested it would press ahead because "backstop" measures were required.

Jo Swyngedouw, chair of the EBA's remuneration working group, said: "You can argue and debate on the absolute level that should be taken into account. Are there exceptions? Possible. I think we will not close that door. Let's have a debate.

"We have to come up with an alternative and part of that alternative is backstop measures and then we can debate on … the level of threshold but I think that is the starting point."

webTitle: Piper Alpha disaster: how 167 oil rig workers died

fields.standfirst: Report into the 1988 disaster made over 100 recommendations about how safety should be improved in North Sea
fields.body:
The Piper Alpha disaster which killed 167 workers on 6 July 1988 off the coast of Aberdeen is the world'sdeadliest ever oil rig accident.

The controversy around it was heightened when a report into the disaster by Lord Cullen judged that the operator Occidental Petroleum had used inadequate maintenance and safety procedures. He made more than 100 recommendations about how safety should be improved in the North Sea.

Along with other oil companies, Occidental had massively scaled back spending as the price of oil had plunged from more than $30 per barrel to $8 in the 1980s compared to today's level of more than $100.

Piper Alpha was once Britain's biggest single oil and gas producing platform, bringing more than 300,000 barrels of crude a day – 10% of the country's total – from below the seabed 125 miles north-east of Aberdeen.

It was owned by a consortium of foreign companies including Texaco and operated by Los Angeles-based Occidental, which sold off its UK interests soon after the disaster to concentrate on the US and Middle East.

Oil was discovered at the Piper field in 1973 and was brought on stream three years later. By 1980 the steel platform was modified to also take gas and was connected by pipeline to the Orkney Islands.

The original modules on the structure were carefully located, with the staff quarters kept well away from the most dangerous production parts of the platform. But this safety feature was diluted when the gas compression units were installed next to the central control room. Further dangers arose when Occidental decided to keep the platform producing oil and gas as it set about a series of construction, maintenance and upgrade works.

A lack of communication at a shift change meant staff were not aware that they should not use a key piece of pipework which had been sealed with a temporary cover and no safety valve. Gas leaked out and ignited while firewalls that would have resisted fire on an oil platform failed to cope with the ensuing gas explosion.

When the platform blew 167 out of 228 workers either on the rig or one of the safety standby vessels patrolling it died. The platform was completely destroyed and it took almost three weeks for the fire to be brought under control by famed American wild well controller, Red Adair.

The accident cost the Lloyd's insurance marketmore than £1bn, making it the largest insured man-made catastrophe. Occidental paid out $100m (£66m) to families of the deceased but escaped any kind of criminal or civil sanction. No one was made personally liable in the courts either.

webTitle: Dovish central banks send markets soaring as Greece's Troika talks drag on - as it happened

fields.bodyText: And as I flee the building, the Portuguese PM Pedro Passos Coelho briefs journlists in Lisbon that he's made some progress today 18:46 - PORTUGAL PRIME MINISTER SAYS WILL DO EVERYTHING POSSIBLE TO GUARANTEE GOVT CAN CONTINUE 18:47 - PORTUGAL PRIME MINISTER SAYS FOUND FORMULA TO MAINTAIN GOVERNMENT STABILITY And here's the details, hot off the Reuters terminal: Portugal's prime minister said on Thursday he has found a way to maintain government stability with the junior partner in the ruling coalition after two of his senior ministers resigned. "A formula was found to maintain government stability," Prime Minister Pedro Passos Coelho told journalists after meeting with the country's president to discuss a political crisis which threatens the government. There's a good video here from WSJ Live, in which Dow Jones's Katie Martin explains today's central bank action: Time to wrap up. Here's a very brisk reminder of the main events, after a fast-moving afternoon dominated by unexpected action by the central bankers. • European stock markets have surged, and the euro and pound have fallen, after the UK and European central banks both moved to counter speculation that monetary policy will be tightened. The FTSE 100 surged 3%, its biggest rise in over 18 months, as traders anticipated a longer period of ultra-loose monetary policy. See 5.14pm and 3.35pm for details and reaction. • The Bank of England started the rally by issuing a surprise statement at noon today (full text at 12.06pm) In another sign of a change of approach under new governor Mark Carney, the BoE released comments in which it stated that the financial markets had got carried away with their UK interest rate rises (in 2015, the FT calculated). See 12.00pm onwards for details and reaction. • The European Central Bank then added to the drama, by issuing 'forward guidance' on interest rates for the first time in its history. In what Mario Draghi called an 'unprecedented move', the ECB said rates would probably remain at their current low levels, or be cut again, for an 'extended period'. Although this wasn't wildly different from existing market expectations, the move was seen as a more dovish touch from Draghi and the Frankfurt-based ECB. (see 1.35pm for highlights of the press conference). • In the eurozone crisis, Greece continued to negotiate with the Troika (IMF, EU, ECB) over its (non?) compliance with the terms of its bailout programme. Talks continue to focus on plans to lay off thousands of civil servants, and park many more in a labour pool on lower wages. Speaking this afternoon, finance minister Yannis Stournaras said he hoped to get a deal by Monday: Talks will continue tonight, tomorrow, the day after and on Sunday...We are heading for agreement on Monday. More from Athens at 4.18pm. • While in Portugal, there is speculation that a deal to shore up its coalition government is close. Prime minister Pedro Passos Coelho met with junior partner Paulo Portas -- and there are rumours that Portas might 'unresign' and become economy minister. A breakthrough could come this evening... (or might not). See 1.22pm for more. I'll be back tomorrow, when the financial markets will be gripped by the excitement of the latest US unemployment data – and what it means for the Fed's stimulus plans. Until then, thanks and goodnight. GW Over in Greece, the panel investigating the so-called Lagarde list of suspected tax evaders – which disappeared after being handed over to Athens – has recommended that charges are brought against former finance minister Giorgos Papaconstantinou (our Athens correspondent Helena Smith flags up). There's a bit more detail here Here's a few comment pieces and research notes on today's central bank action that caught my eye. In the FT, Gavyn Davies explains that the central banks have embraced forward guidance after interest rates fell to such record low levels, meaning they couldn't communicate policy through rate cuts. He concludes: First, any exit from extraordinary accommodation by the Fed is not likely to be followed by other central banks, which are more likely actually to ease in response to any global effects from the Fed. Markets have already responded to this, and the message for the dollar seems clear. Second, at the BoE, Mark Carney is probably looking for a significant regime change, not just a “steady as she goes” opening to his term of office, and he must be getting some encouragement from other MPC members in making this change. Third, the bias towards easier policy at the ECB is greater than many expected, but the weapons available to them are not all that convincing. More here: We are all forward guiders now Frederik Ducrozet of Credit Agricole also draws three conclusions from the ECB's press conference today, in a new research note: • In an unprecedented move by ECB standards, Mario Draghi gave more explicit guidance about the future path of policy rates, which will remain at low levels “for an extended period of time”. This decision on forward guidance was unanimous, adding to the credibility and market impact of the announcement. • Effective action cannot be ruled out in the future, including a further cut in policy rates or liquidity-easing measures, depending on the macro-financial outlook. However, communication will now de facto become the ECB’s main policy tool. • The bullish, periphery-friendly response by the market is unlikely to be a flash in the pan, with Draghi and the ECB back to "whatever it takes" form, risk perceptions for duration and credit should be adjusted downward Here's the full note: ECB: Whatever It Says (pdf) And the BBC has published a handy explainer on forward guidance: Q&A: What is 'forward guidance'? Fuelled by dovish central banks, the FTSE 100 index of blue-chip shares has closed over 3% higher, up a hefty 191 points at 6421. That's its biggest percentage rise since November 2011, and the biggest points jump in nearly two years. Traders clearly welcomed the prospect of interest rates remaining at their current record low levels for a while yet. The surge added more than £48bn to the value of Britain's biggest companies (and the various international firms that also make up the Footsie). That's almost exactly as much as was lost two weeks ago, after the Federal Reserve started talking about stopping its stimulus package by next summer. The other European markets finished at least 2% higher, with the FTSE MIB soaring by 3.4%. And the pound is still down heavily against the US dollar, having lost 2 cents to $1.5070. Brenda Kelly, senior market strategist at IG Index said the equity markets had enjoyed "a free lunch" today: Little was expected from either the European Central Bank or Bank of England today, yet much was delivered. While both interest rates remained unchanged, the central banks appeared to be at pains to appease investors’ fears that tighter monetary policy was imminent. While we cannot suggest that this was a co-ordinated move from both central banks, there is a certain tendency to assume that this unprecedented rhetoric could be an attempt to temper the recent hawkish tones emanating from the US Federal Reserve. See 3.35pm for more markets reaction. The European Central Bank's new flirtation with forward guidance isn't enough for the International Monetary Fund. The IMF declared this afternoon that the ECB should make large amounts of liquidity available to eurozone banks, on top of its existing schemes, to drive a recovery. It also wants the eurozone central bank to provide more help to small firms. The advice came as the IMF cut its economic forecasts for Italy. It now expects a 1.8% contraction this year, down from 1.5% previously. The iMF urged Italy to make more structural reforms, raise inheritance tax and combat tax evasion more effectively, adding: Italy’s efforts should be complemented at the euro area level with steps to strengthen the currency union and support growth. Direct asset purchases by the ECB, such as for SME credits, another LTRO of considerable tenor, and lower haircuts on eligible collateral would help lower bank funding costs and lending rates. Greece claims to be getting closer to a deal with the Troika over its €8bn bailout payment, but the deadlock is likely to last until the weekend, at least...... While the Bank of England and the ECB were stealing the headlines, the Greek government continued to hold talks with top officials from the IMF, the ECB and the EC. Finance minister Yannis Stournaras emerged from the prime minister's office this afternoon to tell the press that progress was being made. However, the two sides remain divided over issues such as the layoff of thousands of civil servants, so its €8bn aid tranche remains up in the air. Stournaras revealed that talks will continue on Sunday, ahead of Monday's meeting of eurozone finance ministers. Administrative reform minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis, responsible for overhauling the public sector, met the Troika this morning. Afterwards, he told reporters that the talks were "tough" and would continue on Friday. Across Europe shares are soaring, government debt is rallying, and the pound and euro have fallen sharply after the Bank of England, and the European Central Bank, stunned the financial markets with new, more dovish predictions on interest rates and monetary stimulus measures. In London the FTSE 100 has surged by 3%, gaining 187 points to 6417, with other European markets posting big gains too. In the currency markets, the pound has shed two cents against the US dollar to a low of $1.508, the lowest level since May. The selloff began after the Bank of England, in a surprise move, released a statement after today's rate-setting meeting in which it warned that the financial markets had got carried away by pushing up UK borrowing costs. The statement, released after governor Mark Carney's first MPC meeting, was seen as a signal that UK monetary policy will remain loose for some time. (see 12.00 onwards for the statement, and reaction). Robert Wood of Berenberg Bank explained that the "persuasive Canadian" was already moving the Bank of England into new territory: Carney appears to be doing a good job of convincing his colleagues of the need for clear guidance to the markets and the public in order to keep market rate expectations in check and cement the recovery. The Euro shed a cent against the US dollar to $1.291, after the ECB took the "unprecented" move to issue forward guidance, and declare that eurozone interest rates will remain at their record lows, or be cut, for "an extended period" (full coverage of the ECB's press conference from 1.35pm) Kit Juckes of Soc Gen commented: The Q&A saw an interminable discussion of what extended means but we'll call it 'a good bit longer than a year' and 18 months seems a fair bet. There is a much better than even chance of another rate cut before we are done. Such predictions helped to drive shares higher across Europe, with the German DAX and French CAC both up over 2%, and Spain's IBEX up 3%. And borrowing costs have fallen for governments across Europe, with British 10-year gilt yields dropping to 2.38%. Here's more reaction to the theme of the day, forward guidance on monetary policy. Scott Corfe of CEBR says Mark Carney could help the UK economy if he went further in August and promised low rates for a long time, as Mario Draghi appeared to today. If policymakers can credibly convince businesses that interest rates will remain at rock bottom levels for several more years, they may become more willing to make investment plans. Households may also be more willing to part with their cash if they are assured that mortgage interest payments won’t rise sharply anytime soon. By removing one element of economic uncertainty, Carney may be able to put the UK economy on firmer ground. On the other hand, Marc Ostwald of Monument Securities reckons Mario Draghi pulled off a "bravura performance in blag and bluff": Let us give Draghi some very respectful credit on the rhetoric front: he has today been "selling the dummy" of 'forward guidance' as near revolutionary for the ECB, given the previous mantra of "we not not pre-commit" ... but were markets really thinking ECB rates might rise in the next 12 months, which is all that he has excluded? Aurelija Augulyte of Nordea Markets warns that central bankers must be cautious: While financial journalist Todd Buell takes an alternative view: The key point from Mario Draghi's press conference (from 1.35pm) is that Europe's central bank is prepared to do more to stimulate the struggling eurozone economy, and it wants everyone to know it. By embracing forward guidance, and predicting that rates will stay low or get lower for some time, the ECB has shown a new, more dovish side. Draghi denies that he's been bounced into action by the US Fed's plans to bring its bond-buying plan to a halt. He also insists he's not acting in concert with new boy Mark Carney at the Bank of England (see its own statement at 12.06pm). But it's clear that we're in a new phase of monetary policy, terms of how it's communicated. At the same time, though, the current age of ultra-low interest rates and stimulus measures isn't over yet.... Draghi defends his precious OMT programme, as the anniversary of his pledge to do "whatever it takes, within the ECB's mandate" to preserve the euro approaches. He denies that he took the pressure off eurozone governments to reform. Those who think governments were given an excuse not to act are "heroes of the counterfactual", he argues. Nice phrase... And finally, Draghi says that "we all agree" that low levels of interest rates can pose risks to financial stability. However, the ECB does not see such risks at this time. And that's the end of the press conference.... Asked about Portugal (where the government's future remains in doubt - see 1.22pm), Mario Draghi says the Lisbon government has achieved "very remarkable results...if not outstanding".He also pays tribute to Vitor Gaspar, who just resigned as finance minister this week, and also his successor, Maria Luis de Albuquerque. The ECB is "reassured" by her appointment, he says, having worked with her at various meeting. From this point of view, Portugal is in safe hands. Honestly, Mario. Asked once again by the Financial Times's Michael Steen about the legal framework for the ECB's bond-buying programme (OMT), Draghi says it is still being worked on and will be published when a country asks for OMT help. No point publishing the terms of the scheme earlier, Draghi smiles...... Draghi continues to deny that the European Central Bank has been bounced into giving forward guidance by the Federal Reserve's talk of slowing its stimulus package this year. However, he also talks about the ECB having to react to instability elsewhere in the world -- and a key factor there is the Fed's plans for tapering.... The Brussels press pack is terribly excited by Mario Draghi's unprecented forward guidance today, that the ECB will keep interest rates at their current, or lower, levels, for an extended period. Is this a change of policy, after 10 years of refusing to precommit? Draghi admits that it is, saying that the ECB now wants to give a "downward bias" to interest rates. But what about inflation? Draghi replies: Our priority is to maintain price stability -- price stability goes in both directions Draghi won't give any views on Greece's current negotiations with the Troika, but points out that Greece has made "significant progress" since its bailout started. We should achnowledge that, he says. Draghi also says the ECB had "an extensive discussion about a possible interest rate cut": How long is an extended period of time? Draghi won't say, but he says the ECB is watching a range of economic indicators when setting interest rates. The ECB has an open mind on many issues, including possibly cutting its deposit rate (on bank deposits) into negative territory. Here's a link to Draghi's statement: Draghi is asked about the report last week about Italy facing heavy losses over derivatives contracts taken out before it entered the euro, and when the ECB governor was in charge of the Italian Treasury. Draghi issues a full-throated defence -- insisting that the contracts (which the FT claims have run up a €8bn loss) were fully legal, and in line with official regulations. They've been fully checked, he insists. These derivative contracts were only taken out to protect Italy from losses in the foreign exchange markets.... "This is the only reason they are made". Transparancy and accountability are vital, he added. First question: will the ECB join the Bank of England in issuing forward guidance? Draghi accuses his questioner of not paying attention, and points to his comments about the governing council expecting all its interest rates to remain at current of low levels. It's an "unprecented step" Draghi said.. "It's the first time that the governing council has said [this]". It's also a coincidence that this happens on the same day as the Bank of England showing its own dovish plumage, Draghi smiles. (of course, this is the first time either central bank has met officially since the Federal Reserve's comments on slowing its QE programme, last month). In answer to a second question, Draghi reveals that today's decisions were all unanimous. Draghi is also warning that the eurozone suffers from weak loan dynamics, due to the weak state of the business cycle, credit risks and balance sheet adjustment. The euro has fallen sharply as soon as Mario Draghi gave his forward guidance, and is down almost 1 cent against the US dollar today. An early shock from Mario Draghi -- he tells his press conference that the ECB expects to maintain interest rates at their current or lower levels for an extended period of time. That's forward guidance in anyone's book -- just 90 minutes after the Bank of England's own surprise statement. Draghi adds that the ECB will keep an accomodative monetary policy stance for as long as necessary. Risks to economic growth are to the downside, he says Draghi says that confidence indicators in the eurozone show a recovery, from 'low levels'. The European Central Bank press conference is underway. Mario Draghi's reading out his statement (it'll be online soon). He's explaining that the ECB still expects an economic recovery to begin later this year, and continue through 2014. Local media in Portugal are reporting that a deal may be emerging between prime minister Pedro Passos Coelho, and junior coalition partner Paulo Portas. But speculation of a "new compromise" with the Troika is hitting Portugal's debt..... The two men held their second meeting in as many days today, following Portas's shock resignation as foreign minister on Tuesday night. According to one report, Portas might return to the government in the role of Deputy PM and economy minister. That would give him, and his party, more influence over Portugal's economic policies. There are also reports that the Lisbon government might seek some concessions from its lenders, in an attempt to ease the burden of its austerity package. Open Europe's Vincenzo Scarpetta flags up the details: And those reports are causing concern in the financial markets, and hitting Portuguese debt again. Having strengthened in early trading, Portugal's 10-year bonds are dropping in value again, pushing up their yield to as high as 7.6% (Tradeweb data). The real ECB drama starts in 45 minutes, at Mario Draghi's press conference. Cue a dash for sandwiches across the City (for those who can leave their desks...) No drama from the ECB, yet.... It has voted to leave interest unchanged, which means the headline cost of borrowing remains at the record low of 0.5%. The ECB also left its deposit rate (what it pays banks to leave money with it) unchanged at 0.0% -- so no negative rates yet. And the marginal rate, which it charges banks when they borrow from it, sticks at 1%. Howard Archer of IHS Global Insight says today's Bank of England statement shows ite monetary policy committee is moving towards a policy of providing more communications about its decisions: With gilt yields having recently been sent significantly higher amid increased global financial market turmoil, the MPC likely felt it was a good move to make it clear at an early stage that any tightening in UK monetary policy is a considerable was off. RBC Capital Markets agrees that the statement is an early move towards giving 'forward guidance' of the Bank's future intentions, adding: The fact that the MPC has decided to express such a clear view about market rates is also a sign of a more aggressive stance in terms of communication. We think forward guidance will be introduced in August.. the MPC under Mark Carney is likely to focus more on communication, restraining the rise in the expected path for future policy rates but with less emphasis on gilt purchases. This, of course, will not be the only policy initiative from the Bank: over the coming months, we expect to see further measures to ease credit conditions, particularly for the SME sector. The Bank of England's dovish comments on inflation and interest rates sparked a robust exchange of views from two former policymakers, David Blanchflower and Andrew Sentance: There are two key phrases in the Bank of England's surprise statement (see 12.06pm) 1) The first is that "the implied rise in the expected future path of Bank Rate was not warranted by the recent developments in the domestic economy". Broadly translated, that means bond yields have risen too high in recent weeks. From 1.6% at the start of May, the yield on Britain's 10-year debt hit 2.5% and the end of June. That was driven by fears in the financial markets that the US is about to slow its stimulus programme. 2) "Twelve-month CPI inflation rose to 2.7% in May and is set to rise further in the near term. Further out, inflation should fall back towards the 2% target..." That suggests the MPC isn't considering tightening monetary policy to control the rising cost of living. So, no chance of an early interest rate rise, or an end to quantitative easing. That's why the pound's falling, as traders pile into gilts and shares. The days of loose monetary policy in the UK aren't over.... Shares are rallying in London, though -- with the FTSE 100 up 114 points, or 1.8%, at 6344. UK government debt, or gilts, are also rallying. That has pushed down the yield on Britain's 10-year debt to 2.35%, from around 2.4% before the Bank of England's statement. The pound has tumbled by more than a cent against the US dollar after the Bank of England took the rate step of issuing a statement. From $1.526 before the statement was released, the pound has now dropped $1.5117. Here's the offficial text of the statement released by the Bank of England at noon, alongside its decision on rates on QE. Since the May Inflation Report, market interest rates have risen sharply internationally and asset prices have been volatile. In the United Kingdom, there have been further signs that a recovery is in train, although it remains weak by historical standards and a degree of slack is expected to persist for some time. Twelve-month CPI inflation rose to 2.7% in May and is set to rise further in the near term. Further out, inflation should fall back towards the 2% target as external price pressures fade and a revival in productivity growth curbs domestic cost pressures. At its meeting today, the Committee noted that the incoming data over the past couple of months had been broadly consistent with the central outlook for output growth and inflation contained in the May Report. The significant upward movement in market interest rates would, however, weigh on that outlook; in the Committee’s view, the implied rise in the expected future path of Bank Rate was not warranted by the recent developments in the domestic economy. The latest remit letter to the MPC from the Chancellor had requested that the Committee provide an assessment, alongside its August Inflation Report, of the case for adopting some form of forward guidance, including the possible use of intermediate thresholds. This analysis would have an important bearing on the Committee’s policy discussions in August. In the light of these considerations, the Committee voted to maintain the size of its programme of asset purchases financed by the issuance of central bank reserves at £375 billion. The Committee also voted to maintain Bank Rate at 0.5%. The minutes of the meeting will be published at 9.30am on Wednesday 17 July. [end] The Bank of England's monetary policy committee has voted to leave UK interest rates at the current record low of 0.5%, and also left its quantitative easing programme unchanged. And there's a statement,..... Twenty minutes to go until the central bank fun begins, starting with the Bank of England's decision on monetary policy. City economists are broadly united in expecting no change in interest rates, or in Britain's quantitative easing programme (the BoE has already spent £375bn buying up government debt). City brokerage Abshire-Smith explains: Interest rates are expected to be left unchanged at the record low of 0.50%, with asset purchases (QE) to be held steady at £375bn. However if the expected happens (both left unchanged) it should leave traders slightly disappointed with Carney’s first week in office being an anti-climax. There's always the (small?) possibility of a statement from the Monetary Policy Committee. After such a quiet morning, the City is hoping for more action. Developments in Greece (finally) -- administrative reform minister Kyriakos Mitsotak has concluded today's meeting with Troika officials over the vexed issue of civil service layoffs. Mitsotak is now discussing the situation with prime minister Antonis Samaras - who is due to sit down with the Troika himself soon. It's a busy day for Samaras. He's already held talks with German foreign minister Guido Westerwelle this morning: Yesterday, Westerwelle ruled out another debt writedown for Greece, and suggested that the country's prospects were finally improving: My impression is that we for the first time are seeing a faint silver lining on the horizon. Greek finance minister Yannis Stournaras (on the left) looked pretty serious this morning as he chatted with the government's spokesman, Simos Kedikoglou at prime minister Antonis Stournaras's office: The political disagreements in Portugal didn't prevent Spain or France from selling debt this morning, although the cost of borrowing did rise slightly. The Spanish treasury sold three-year bonds at an average yield of 2.875%, up from 2.706%, as it raised a total of €4bn from the markets. France raised €8bn, but also saw yields inch higher. The Portuguese turmoil may have inflamed eurozone crisis fears, but it has also made other euro area debt look more attractive in comparison, argued Nick Stamenkovic, bond strategist at RIA Capital Markets. He explained: The recent Portuguese-driven correction has enhanced the attractiveness of Spanish bonds and the auction was taken down very well. The outlook in Portugal is very clouded. What's interesting is that Italy and Spain have been relatively resilient. The contagion is very limited and a sign that investors see those problems as very localised and don't see them being a threat to the euro zone. Nikos Dendias, Greece's minister of Public Order and Citizen Protection, has declared that the Greek goevrnment shouldn't be blamed if, as seems likely, it fails to persuade the Troika that bailout targets are being met. Appearing on CNBC, Dendias argued that Greece was doing its best to comply with an imperfect financial programme. saying: The plan is hardly our fault. We're co-responsible in a sense [for Greek debt levels before the bailout] but I'm sure that the European institutions saw a bubble being created in Greece and nobody really warned us about being more careful. I'm not saying we're not at fault, but there are others at fault. I see Europe as a family and as European friends and partners, so it's everybody's fault. But the main question is how we go forward, not to start a blame game…We will do better in the future I am confident about that. More details here Dendias's comment come after finance ministry officials told Reuters yesterday that there was no real chance of meeting the Troika's demands in time for next Monday's eurogroup meeting. That would mean that the next Greek aid payment, worth €8bn, might not be paid immediately - or only paid in installments. Over in Athens, top officials from the Troika will hold further talks today with administrative reform minister Kyriakos Mitsotak over Greece's bailout programme and planned civil service job cuts. Mitsotak is under pressure to press on with moving 12,500 public servants into a labour mobility scheme, on lower wages and the risk of being fired if new jobs can't be found. Greece is also meant to be cutting 4,000 civil service positions. And local media say the EBC-IMF-EC officials aren't willing to count the staff who are being laid off at state broadcaster ERT. Kathimerini explains: Sources at the Administrative Reform Ministry told Kathimerini on Wednesday that “the basis for reaching an agreement is in place.” One of the key problems is that the visiting inspectors refuse to recognize the 2,600 sackings at public broadcaster ERT as permanent dismissals. Until they are given detailed plans of how the new broadcaster will operate and how many employees it will take on, the officials will not accept that the government has carried out any firings. So after all the anger and aggrevation over the sudden closure of ERT, it may not help Greece's case with the Troika after all... Another reason for the bounceback on the Portuguese stock market is that Lisbon's financial regulator banned short-selling of four companies, including three banks whose shares all tumbled over 10% yesterday. This prevents traders from selling shares they don't own, with a plan to buy them back cheaper after they've been routed. And this morning, the UK's Financial Conduct Authority followed suit. It has prohibited anyone in the City from shorting Banco Comercial Portugues, Banco Espirito Santo or Sonae Industria. The ban expires at midnight..... Here's their announcement. Optimism abounds on Portugal's stock market - the PSI 20 is now up 3.5% on hopes that the country's leaders can resolve the crisis. Portugal's prime minister, Pedro Passos Coelho, is reported to have held "very constructive" talks last night with his junior coalition partner, Paulo Portas. That's via the Wall Street Journal's Patricia Kowsmann, in Lisbon. A reminder about the political situation -- Passos Coelho's Social Democrats govern in a coalition with Portas's CDS-PP, or Conservative Popular Party. If CDS walk away then Passos Coelho could lose his majority. He could lead a minority government, but would be at risk of losing a confidence vote. Passos Coelho had initially refused to accept Portas's resignation as foreign minister. And last night, CDS said that it didn't expect any oher ministers to also resign. Here's an early assessment of the situation today from Kit Juckes of Société Générale: Portuguese political leaders are planning to hold talks to ease the country's political crisis, and even if they can't calm nerves completely, 10yr yields have already dropped back 30 basis points from last night's close. With the US on holiday, the ECB meeting take centre stage. The UK MPC is also meeting. At some point, Mr Carney is going to want to shake things up in terms of post-meeting communication, but this week may be just a bit too soon. Shares are also bouncing back on the Lisbon stock market. After yesterday's 5% tumble, the PSI 20 is up over 2% on hopes that the Portuguese government won't collapse. Every share is up, led by banking stocks, which suffered badly yesterday. Prime minister Pedro Passos Coelho insisted yesterday evening that he could ride out the storm. The news that his junior coalition partner hasn't jumped ship (yet, anyway), is fuelling optimism. And here's the details: • PSI 20: up 112 points at 5,348, +2.1% • FTSE 100: up 56 points at 6285, +0.9% • German DAX: up 72 points at 7901, + 0.9% • French CAC: up 42 points at 3744, +1.15% • Spanish IBEX up 51 points at 7807, +0.5% • Italian FTSE MIB: up 103 points at 15376, + 0.68% And here's a graph of Portuguese 10-year bond yields this week, showing the sharp fall this morning back towards safer levels after yesterday's alarm: After an alarming day yesterday, the situation in Portugal appears to be easing. Portuguese government bonds are recovering some value in early trading, after yesterday's sharp selloff. And the European stock markets are bouncing back too. This follows the news last last night that the junior coalition partner (CDS) in the Portuguese government has pledged to play its part in holding the government together. Their party leader had sparked the crisis by dramatically quitting as foreign minister on Tuesday. With the Portuguese president holding talks with party leaders today, there is hope that a deal can be hammered out to hold Pedro Passos Coelho's government together. This has pushed up the value of Portugal's debt, driving down the value (effectively the interest rate) on its 10-year bonds to just 7.24%, from 7.5% last night. That's a sign of traders are less alarmed about the Lisbon situation. Shares are also up across Europe -- details to follow..... Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the latest events in the eurozone, the financial crisis and the global economy. It's Central Banks day in Europe, with the Bank of England and the European Central Bank's top officials gathering to set monetary policy in Britain and the eurozone. And that means ECB president Mario Draghi facing the press this afternoon, at a time when the eurozone crisis is picking up pace again. The political turmoil that broke out in Portugal this week is another reminder that, for all Draghi's talk of doing 'whatever it takes' to protect the euro, this remains a poitical crisis as well as an economic, financial and social one. Analysts don't expect a cut in eurozone interest rates, but as ever, what Draghi says is almost as interesting as what he actually does. Carsten Brzeski of ING reckons the ECB president will urge the markets to stay calm, and pledge not to tighten monetary policy anytime soon: In our view, the ECB remains in crisis mode. The eurozone economy is still lagging far behind the US economy and exit discussions at a moment in which the economy is showing that signs of a bottoming out are more than premature. Draghi is also bound to field questions over issues such as whether the ECB is close to imposing negative interest rates on banks, and its promises of more support to help small firms borrow. Draghi's views on Greece, where the government continues to meet with the Troika in an attempt to unlock its next €8bn bailout loans, could also be interesting... At the Bank of England, it's the first time that new governor Mark Carney has voted on UK interest rates and quantitative easing. We're not expecting any fireworks – recent UK data has been quite upbeat – but you never know how the new man might shake things up.... I'll be watching both the Bank of England (decision at noon BST) and the European Central Bank (decision at 12.45pm, press conference at 1.30pm), along with the latest developments across the eurozone.
