fields.headline: Dovish central banks send markets soaring as Greece's Troika talks drag on - as it happened
fields.body:
6.58pm BST

PPS: a few Portuguese news flashes

And as I flee the building, the Portuguese PM Pedro Passos Coelho briefs journlists in Lisbon that he's made some progress today

18:46 - PORTUGAL PRIME MINISTER SAYS WILL DO EVERYTHING POSSIBLE TO GUARANTEE GOVT CAN CONTINUE

18:47 - PORTUGAL PRIME MINISTER SAYS FOUND FORMULA TO MAINTAIN GOVERNMENT STABILITY 

And here's the details, hot off the Reuters terminal:

Portugal's prime minister said on Thursday he has found a way to maintain government stability with the junior partner in the ruling coalition after two of his senior ministers resigned.

"A formula was found to maintain government stability," Prime Minister Pedro Passos Coelho told journalists after meeting with the country's president to discuss a political crisis which threatens the government.

6.53pm BST

PS....

There's a good video here from WSJ Live, in which Dow Jones's Katie Martin explains today's central bank action:

Updated at 6.54pm BST

6.44pm BST

Closing summary

Time to wrap up. Here's a very brisk reminder of the main events, after a fast-moving afternoon dominated by unexpected action by the central bankers.

• European stock markets have surged, and the euro and pound have fallen, after the UK and European central banks both moved to counter speculation that monetary policy will be tightened.

The FTSE 100 surged 3%, its biggest rise in over 18 months, as traders anticipated a longer period of ultra-loose monetary policy. See 5.14pm and 3.35pm for details and reaction.

• The Bank of England started the rally by issuing a surprise statement at noon today (full text at 12.06pm)

In another sign of a change of approach under new governor Mark Carney, the BoE released comments in which it stated that the financial markets had got carried away with their UK interest rate rises (in 2015, the FT calculated). See 12.00pm onwards for details and reaction.

• The European Central Bank then added to the drama, by issuing 'forward guidance' on interest rates for the first time in its history. In what Mario Draghi called an 'unprecedented move', the ECB said rates would probably remain at their current low levels, or be cut again, for an 'extended period'.

Although this wasn't wildly different from existing market expectations, the move was seen as a more dovish touch from Draghi and the Frankfurt-based ECB. (see 1.35pm for highlights of the press conference).

• In the eurozone crisis, Greece continued to negotiate with the Troika (IMF, EU, ECB) over its (non?) compliance with the terms of its bailout programme. Talks continue to focus on plans to lay off thousands of civil servants, and park many more in a labour pool on lower wages.

Speaking this afternoon, finance minister Yannis Stournaras said he hoped to get a deal by Monday:

Talks will continue tonight, tomorrow, the day after and on Sunday...We are heading for agreement on Monday.

More from Athens at 4.18pm.

• While in Portugal, there is speculation that a deal to shore up its coalition government is close. Prime minister Pedro Passos Coelho met with junior partner Paulo Portas -- and there are rumours that Portas might 'unresign' and become economy minister. A breakthrough could come this evening... (or might not). See 1.22pm for more.

I'll be back tomorrow, when the financial markets will be gripped by the excitement of the latest US unemployment data – and what it means for the Fed's stimulus plans. Until then, thanks and goodnight. GW

Updated at 6.48pm BST

6.18pm BST

Over in Greece, the panel investigating the so-called Lagarde list of suspected tax evaders – which disappeared after being handed over to Athens – has recommended that charges are brought against former finance minister Giorgos Papaconstantinou (our Athens correspondent Helena Smith flags up). There's a bit more detail here

5.58pm BST

Central Bank moves: further reading

Here's a few comment pieces and research notes on today's central bank action that caught my eye.

In the FT, Gavyn Davies explains that the central banks have embraced forward guidance after interest rates fell to such record low levels, meaning they couldn't communicate policy through rate cuts.

He concludes:

  • First, any exit from extraordinary accommodation by the Fed is not likely to be followed by other central banks, which are more likely actually to ease in response to any global effects from the Fed. Markets have already responded to this, and the message for the dollar seems clear.
  • Second, at the BoE, Mark Carney is probably looking for a significant regime change, not just a “steady as she goes” opening to his term of office, and he must be getting some encouragement from other MPC members in making this change.
  • Third, the bias towards easier policy at the ECB is greater than many expected, but the weapons available to them are not all that convincing.

More here: We are all forward guiders now

Frederik Ducrozet of Credit Agricole also draws three conclusions from the ECB's press conference today, in a new research note:

• In an unprecedented move by ECB standards, Mario Draghi gave more explicit guidance about the future path of policy rates, which will remain at low levels “for an extended period
of time”. This decision on forward guidance was unanimous, adding to the credibility and market impact of the announcement.
• Effective action cannot be ruled out in the future, including a further cut in policy rates or liquidity-easing measures, depending on the macro-financial outlook. However,
communication will now de facto become the ECB’s main policy tool.
• The bullish, periphery-friendly response by the market is unlikely to be a flash in the pan, with Draghi and the ECB back to "whatever it takes" form, risk perceptions for duration and
credit should be adjusted downward

Here's the full note: ECB: Whatever It Says (pdf)

And the BBC has published a handy explainer on forward guidance: Q&A: What is 'forward guidance'?

5.14pm BST

FTSE 100 leaps

Fuelled by dovish central banks, the FTSE 100 index of blue-chip shares has closed over 3% higher, up a hefty 191 points at 6421.

That's its biggest percentage rise since November 2011, and the biggest points jump in nearly two years. Traders clearly welcomed the prospect of interest rates remaining at their current record low levels for a while yet.

The surge added more than £48bn to the value of Britain's biggest companies (and the various international firms that also make up the Footsie).

That's almost exactly as much as was lost two weeks ago, after the Federal Reserve started talking about stopping its stimulus package by next summer. 

The other European markets finished at least 2% higher, with the FTSE MIB soaring by 3.4%.

And the pound is still down heavily against the US dollar, having lost 2 cents to $1.5070.

Brenda Kelly, senior market strategist at IG Index said the equity markets had enjoyed "a free lunch" today:

Little was expected from either the European Central Bank or Bank of England today, yet much was delivered. While both interest rates remained unchanged, the central banks appeared to be at pains to appease investors’ fears that tighter monetary policy was imminent.

While we cannot suggest that this was a co-ordinated move from both central banks, there is a certain tendency to assume that this unprecedented rhetoric could be an attempt to temper the recent hawkish tones emanating from the US Federal Reserve.

See 3.35pm for more markets reaction.

Updated at 5.19pm BST

4.57pm BST

IMF wants more from the ECB

The European Central Bank's new flirtation with forward guidance isn't enough for the International Monetary Fund.

The IMF declared this afternoon that the ECB should make large amounts of liquidity available to eurozone banks, on top of its existing schemes, to drive a recovery. It also wants the eurozone central bank to provide more help to small firms.

The advice came as the IMF cut its economic forecasts for Italy. It now expects a 1.8% contraction this year, down from 1.5% previously.

The iMF urged Italy to make more structural reforms, raise inheritance tax and combat tax evasion more effectively, adding:

Italy’s efforts should be complemented at the euro area level with steps to strengthen the currency union and support growth. Direct asset purchases by the ECB, such as for SME credits, another LTRO of considerable tenor, and lower haircuts on eligible collateral would help lower bank funding costs and lending rates.

Updated at 4.57pm BST

4.18pm BST

Greece: "We're making progress"

Greece claims to be getting closer to a deal with the Troika over its €8bn bailout payment, but the deadlock is likely to last until the weekend, at least......

While the Bank of England and the ECB were stealing the headlines, the Greek government continued to hold talks with top officials from the IMF, the ECB and the EC.

Finance minister Yannis Stournaras emerged from the prime minister's office this afternoon to tell the press that progress was being made. However, the two sides remain divided over issues such as the layoff of thousands of civil servants, so its €8bn aid tranche remains up in the air.

Stournaras revealed that talks will continue on Sunday, ahead of Monday's meeting of eurozone finance ministers.

Administrative reform minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis, responsible for overhauling the public sector, met the Troika this morning. Afterwards, he told reporters that the talks were "tough" and would continue on Friday.

3.35pm BST

Stock markets roar ahead

Across Europe shares are soaring, government debt is rallying, and the pound and euro have fallen sharply after the Bank of England, and the European Central Bank, stunned the financial markets with new, more dovish predictions on interest rates and monetary stimulus measures.

In London the FTSE 100 has surged by 3%, gaining 187 points to 6417, with other European markets posting big gains too.

In the currency markets, the pound has shed two cents against the US dollar to a low of $1.508, the lowest level since May. The selloff began after the Bank of England, in a surprise move, released a statement after today's rate-setting meeting in which it warned that the financial markets had got carried away by pushing up UK borrowing costs.

The statement, released after governor Mark Carney's first MPC meeting, was seen as a signal that UK monetary policy will remain loose for some time. (see 12.00 onwards for the statement, and reaction).

Robert Wood of Berenberg Bank explained that the "persuasive Canadian" was already moving the Bank of England into new territory:

Carney appears to be doing a good job of convincing his colleagues of the need for clear guidance to the markets and the public in order to keep market rate expectations in check and cement the recovery.

The Euro shed a cent against the US dollar to $1.291, after the ECB took the "unprecented" move to issue forward guidance, and declare that eurozone interest rates will remain at their record lows, or be cut, for "an extended period" (full coverage of the ECB's press conference from 1.35pm)

Kit Juckes of Soc Gen commented:

The Q&A saw an interminable discussion of what extended means but we'll call it 'a good bit longer than a year' and 18 months seems a fair bet. There is a much better than even chance of another rate cut before we are done.

Such predictions helped to drive shares higher across Europe, with the German DAX and French CAC both up over 2%, and Spain's IBEX up 3%.

And borrowing costs have fallen for governments across Europe, with British 10-year gilt yields dropping to 2.38%.

3.29pm BST

Foward guidance - reaction

Here's more reaction to the theme of the day, forward guidance on monetary policy.

Scott Corfe of CEBR says Mark Carney could help the UK economy if he went further in August and promised low rates for a long time, as Mario Draghi appeared to today.

If policymakers can credibly convince businesses that interest rates will remain at rock bottom levels for several more years, they may become more willing to make investment plans.

Households may also be more willing to part with their cash if they are assured that mortgage interest payments won’t rise sharply anytime soon. By removing one element of economic uncertainty, Carney may be able to put the UK economy on firmer ground.

On the other hand, Marc Ostwald of Monument Securities reckons Mario Draghi pulled off a "bravura performance in blag and bluff":

Let us give Draghi some very respectful credit on the rhetoric front: he has today been "selling the dummy" of 'forward guidance' as near revolutionary for the ECB, given the previous mantra of "we not not pre-commit" ... but were markets really thinking ECB rates might rise in the next 12 months, which is all that he has excluded?

Aurelija Augulyte of Nordea Markets warns that central bankers must be cautious:

While financial journalist Todd Buell takes an alternative view:

Updated at 3.42pm BST

2.39pm BST

Instant summary

The key point from Mario Draghi's press conference (from 1.35pm) is that Europe's central bank is prepared to do more to stimulate the struggling eurozone economy, and it wants everyone to know it.

By embracing forward guidance, and predicting that rates will stay low or get lower for some time, the ECB has shown a new, more dovish side.

Draghi denies that he's been bounced into action by the US Fed's plans to bring its bond-buying plan to a halt. He also insists he's not acting in concert with new boy Mark Carney at the Bank of England (see its own statement at 12.06pm). But it's clear that we're in a new phase of monetary policy, terms of how it's communicated.

At the same time, though, the current age of ultra-low interest rates and stimulus measures isn't over yet....

Updated at 3.06pm BST

2.22pm BST

Draghi defends his precious OMT programme, as the anniversary of his pledge to do "whatever it takes, within the ECB's mandate" to preserve the euro approaches.

He denies that he took the pressure off eurozone governments to reform. Those who think governments were given an excuse not to act are "heroes of the counterfactual", he argues. Nice phrase...

And finally, Draghi says that "we all agree" that low levels of interest rates can pose risks to financial stability. However, the ECB does not see such risks at this time.

And that's the end of the press conference....

Updated at 2.30pm BST

2.20pm BST

Draghi hails Portugal

Asked about Portugal (where the government's future remains in doubt - see 1.22pm), Mario Draghi says the Lisbon government has achieved "very remarkable results...if not outstanding".He also pays tribute to Vitor Gaspar, who just resigned as finance minister this week, and also his successor, Maria Luis de Albuquerque. The ECB is "reassured" by her appointment, he says, having worked with her at various meeting.

From this point of view, Portugal is in safe hands.

2.11pm BST

Honestly, Mario. Asked once again by the Financial Times's Michael Steen about the legal framework for the ECB's bond-buying programme (OMT), Draghi says it is still being worked on and will be published when a country asks for OMT help.

No point publishing the terms of the scheme earlier, Draghi smiles......

Updated at 2.12pm BST

2.09pm BST

Draghi continues to deny that the European Central Bank has been bounced into giving forward guidance by the Federal Reserve's talk of slowing its stimulus package this year.

However, he also talks about the ECB having to react to instability elsewhere in the world -- and a key factor there is the Fed's plans for tapering....

Updated at 2.12pm BST

2.05pm BST

The Brussels press pack is terribly excited by Mario Draghi's unprecented forward guidance today, that the ECB will keep interest rates at their current, or lower, levels, for an extended period.

Is this a change of policy, after 10 years of refusing to precommit?

Draghi admits that it is, saying that the ECB now wants to give a "downward bias" to interest rates.

But what about inflation?

Draghi replies:

Our priority is to maintain price stability -- price stability goes in both directions

2.00pm BST

Draghi: Greece has made progress

Draghi won't give any views on Greece's current negotiations with the Troika, but points out that Greece has made "significant progress" since its bailout started. We should achnowledge that, he says.

1.58pm BST

Draghi also says the ECB had "an extensive discussion about a possible interest rate cut":

1.56pm BST

How long is an extended period of time? Draghi won't say, but he says the ECB is watching a range of economic indicators when setting interest rates.

The ECB has an open mind on many issues, including possibly cutting its deposit rate (on bank deposits) into negative territory.

1.55pm BST

Read the statement

Here's a link to Draghi's statement:

1.53pm BST

Draghi defends role in Italian derivatives

Draghi is asked about the report last week about Italy facing heavy losses over derivatives contracts taken out before it entered the euro, and when the ECB governor was in charge of the Italian Treasury.

Draghi issues a full-throated defence -- insisting that the contracts (which the FT claims have run up a €8bn loss) were fully legal, and in line with official regulations. They've been fully checked, he insists.

These derivative contracts were only taken out to protect Italy from losses in the foreign exchange markets.... "This is the only reason they are made".

Transparancy and accountability are vital, he added.

Updated at 1.55pm BST

1.49pm BST

Question Time:

First question: will the ECB join the Bank of England in issuing forward guidance?

Draghi accuses his questioner of not paying attention, and points to his comments about the governing council expecting all its interest rates to remain at current of low levels.

It's an "unprecented step" Draghi said.. "It's the first time that the governing council has said [this]".

It's also a coincidence that this happens on the same day as the Bank of England showing its own dovish plumage, Draghi smiles.

(of course, this is the first time either central bank has met officially since the Federal Reserve's comments on slowing its QE programme, last month).

In answer to a second question, Draghi reveals that today's decisions were all unanimous.

Updated at 1.49pm BST

1.44pm BST

Draghi is also warning that the eurozone suffers from weak loan dynamics, due to the weak state of the business cycle, credit risks and balance sheet adjustment.

1.41pm BST

Euro falls

The euro has fallen sharply as soon as Mario Draghi gave his forward guidance, and is down almost 1 cent against the US dollar today.

1.40pm BST

FORWARD GUIDANCE FROM DRAGHI

An early shock from Mario Draghi -- he tells his press conference that the ECB expects to maintain interest rates at their current or lower levels for an extended period of time.

That's forward guidance in anyone's book -- just 90 minutes after the Bank of England's own surprise statement.

Draghi adds that the ECB will keep an accomodative monetary policy stance for as long as necessary.

Risks to economic growth are to the downside, he says

Updated at 1.40pm BST

1.38pm BST

Draghi says that confidence indicators in the eurozone show a recovery, from 'low levels'.

1.35pm BST

ECB press conference begins...

The European Central Bank press conference is underway.

Mario Draghi's reading out his statement (it'll be online soon).

He's explaining that the ECB still expects an economic recovery to begin later this year, and continue through 2014.

Updated at 1.35pm BST

1.22pm BST

Progress in Portugal?

Local media in Portugal are reporting that a deal may be emerging between prime minister Pedro Passos Coelho, and junior coalition partner Paulo Portas.

But speculation of a "new compromise" with the Troika is hitting Portugal's debt.....

The two men held their second meeting in as many days today, following Portas's shock resignation as foreign minister on Tuesday night.

According to one report, Portas might return to the government in the role of Deputy PM and economy minister. That would give him, and his party, more influence over Portugal's economic policies.

There are also reports that the Lisbon government might seek some concessions from its lenders, in an attempt to ease the burden of its austerity package.

Open Europe's Vincenzo Scarpetta flags up the details:

And those reports are causing concern in the financial markets, and hitting Portuguese debt again.

Having strengthened in early trading, Portugal's 10-year bonds are dropping in value again, pushing up their yield to as high as 7.6% (Tradeweb data).

12.49pm BST

The real ECB drama starts in 45 minutes, at Mario Draghi's press conference. Cue a dash for sandwiches across the City (for those who can leave their desks...)

12.48pm BST

European Central Bank leaves rates unchanged

No drama from the ECB, yet.... It has voted to leave interest unchanged, which means the headline cost of borrowing remains at the record low of 0.5%.

The ECB also left its deposit rate (what it pays banks to leave money with it) unchanged at 0.0% -- so no negative rates yet.

And the marginal rate, which it charges banks when they borrow from it, sticks at 1%.

12.44pm BST

More Bank of England reaction

Howard Archer of IHS Global Insight says today's Bank of England statement shows ite monetary policy committee is moving towards a policy of providing more communications about its decisions:

With gilt yields having recently been sent significantly higher amid increased global financial market turmoil, the MPC likely felt it was a good move to make it clear at an early stage that any tightening in UK monetary policy is a considerable was off.

RBC Capital Markets agrees that the statement is an early move towards giving 'forward guidance' of the Bank's future intentions, adding:

The fact that the MPC has decided to express such a clear view about market rates is also a sign of a more aggressive stance in terms of communication. We think forward guidance will be introduced in August..

the MPC under Mark Carney is likely to focus more on communication, restraining the rise in the expected path for future policy rates but with less emphasis on gilt purchases. 

This, of course, will not be the only policy initiative from the Bank: over the coming months, we expect to see further measures to ease credit conditions, particularly for the SME sector.

12.38pm BST

Bank of England statement: early reaction

The Bank of England's dovish comments on inflation and interest rates sparked a robust exchange of views from two former policymakers, David Blanchflower and Andrew Sentance:

12.31pm BST

Bank of England statement - what does it mean?

There are two key phrases in the Bank of England's surprise statement (see 12.06pm)

1) The first is that "the implied rise in the expected future path of Bank Rate was not warranted by the recent developments in the domestic economy".

Broadly translated, that means bond yields have risen too high in recent weeks. From 1.6% at the start of May, the yield on Britain's 10-year debt hit 2.5% and the end of June. That was driven by fears in the financial markets that the US is about to slow its stimulus programme.

2) "Twelve-month CPI inflation rose to 2.7% in May and is set to rise further in the near term. Further out, inflation should fall back towards the 2% target..."

That suggests the MPC isn't considering tightening monetary policy to control the rising cost of living.

So, no chance of an early interest rate rise, or an end to quantitative easing. That's why the pound's falling, as traders pile into gilts and shares. The days of loose monetary policy in the UK aren't over....

12.15pm BST

Shares are rallying in London, though -- with the FTSE 100 up 114 points, or 1.8%, at 6344.

12.13pm BST

UK government debt, or gilts, are also rallying.

That has pushed down the yield on Britain's 10-year debt to 2.35%, from around 2.4% before the Bank of England's statement.

12.11pm BST

Pound falls

The pound has tumbled by more than a cent against the US dollar after the Bank of England took the rate step of issuing a statement.

From $1.526 before the statement was released, the pound has now dropped $1.5117.

12.06pm BST

Bank of England statement

Here's the offficial text of the statement released by the Bank of England at noon, alongside its decision on rates on QE.

Since the May Inflation Report, market interest rates have risen sharply internationally and asset prices have been volatile.

In the United Kingdom, there have been further signs that a recovery is in train, although it remains weak by historical standards and a degree of slack is expected to persist for some time.

Twelve-month CPI inflation rose to 2.7% in May and is set to rise further in the near term. Further out, inflation should fall back towards the 2% target as external price pressures fade and a revival in productivity growth curbs domestic cost pressures.

At its meeting today, the Committee noted that the incoming data over the past couple of months had been broadly consistent with the central outlook for output growth and inflation contained in the May Report.

The significant upward movement in market interest rates would, however, weigh on that outlook; in the Committee’s view, the implied rise in the expected future path of Bank Rate was not warranted by the recent developments in the domestic economy.

The latest remit letter to the MPC from the Chancellor had requested that the Committee provide an assessment, alongside its August Inflation Report, of the case for adopting some form of forward guidance, including the possible use of intermediate thresholds.

This analysis would have an important bearing on the Committee’s policy discussions in August. In the light of these considerations, the Committee voted to maintain the size of its programme of asset purchases financed by the issuance of central bank reserves at £375 billion. 

The Committee also voted to maintain Bank Rate at 0.5%. The minutes of the meeting will be published at 9.30am on Wednesday 17 July.

[end]

Updated at 12.06pm BST

12.00pm BST

Bank of England Decision

The Bank of England's monetary policy committee has voted to leave UK interest rates at the current record low of 0.5%, and also left its quantitative easing programme unchanged.

And there's a statement,.....

11.57am BST

11.40am BST

Key event

Twenty minutes to go until the central bank fun begins, starting with the Bank of England's decision on monetary policy.

City economists are broadly united in expecting no change in interest rates, or in Britain's quantitative easing programme (the BoE has already spent £375bn buying up government debt).

City brokerage Abshire-Smith explains:

Interest rates are expected to be left unchanged at the record low of 0.50%, with asset purchases (QE) to be held steady at £375bn. However if the expected happens (both left unchanged) it should leave traders slightly disappointed with Carney’s first week in office being an anti-climax. 

There's always the (small?) possibility of a statement from the Monetary Policy Committee. After such a quiet morning, the City is hoping for more action.

Updated at 11.41am BST

11.33am BST

Developments in Greece (finally) -- administrative reform minister Kyriakos Mitsotak has concluded today's meeting with Troika officials over the vexed issue of civil service layoffs.

Mitsotak is now discussing the situation with prime minister Antonis Samaras - who is due to sit down with the Troika himself soon.

It's a busy day for Samaras. He's already held talks with German foreign minister Guido Westerwelle this morning:

Yesterday, Westerwelle ruled out another debt writedown for Greece, and suggested that the country's prospects were finally improving:

My impression is that we for the first time are seeing a faint silver lining on the horizon.

11.21am BST

Greek finance minister Yannis Stournaras (on the left) looked pretty serious this morning as he chatted with the government's spokesman, Simos Kedikoglou at prime minister Antonis Stournaras's office:

11.12am BST

Bond auctions unshaken

The political disagreements in Portugal didn't prevent Spain or France from selling debt this morning, although the cost of borrowing did rise slightly.

The Spanish treasury sold three-year bonds at an average yield of 2.875%, up from 2.706%, as it raised a total of €4bn from the markets. France raised €8bn, but also saw yields inch higher.

The Portuguese turmoil may have inflamed eurozone crisis fears, but it has also made other euro area debt look more attractive in comparison, argued Nick Stamenkovic, bond strategist at RIA Capital Markets.

He explained:

The recent Portuguese-driven correction has enhanced the attractiveness of Spanish bonds and the auction was taken down very well.

The outlook in Portugal is very clouded. What's interesting is that Italy and Spain have been relatively resilient. The contagion is very limited and a sign that investors see those problems as very localised and don't see them being a threat to the euro zone.

Updated at 11.12am BST

10.27am BST

Greek minister: don't blame us

Nikos Dendias, Greece's minister of Public Order and Citizen Protection, has declared that the Greek goevrnment shouldn't be blamed if, as seems likely, it fails to persuade the Troika that bailout targets are being met.

Appearing on CNBC, Dendias argued that Greece was doing its best to comply with an imperfect financial programme. saying:

The plan is hardly our fault. We're co-responsible in a sense [for Greek debt levels before the bailout] but I'm sure that the European institutions saw a bubble being created in Greece and nobody really warned us about being more careful. I'm not saying we're not at fault, but there are others at fault.

I see Europe as a family and as European friends and partners, so it's everybody's fault. But the main question is how we go forward, not to start a blame game…We will do better in the future I am confident about that.

More details here

Dendias's comment come after finance ministry officials told Reuters yesterday that there was no real chance of meeting the Troika's demands in time for next Monday's eurogroup meeting. That would mean that the next Greek aid payment, worth €8bn, might not be paid immediately - or only paid in installments.

10.11am BST

Over in Athens, top officials from the Troika will hold further talks today with administrative reform minister Kyriakos Mitsotak over Greece's bailout programme and planned civil service job cuts.

Mitsotak is under pressure to press on with moving 12,500 public servants into a labour mobility scheme, on lower wages and the risk of being fired if new jobs can't be found.

Greece is also meant to be cutting 4,000 civil service positions. And local media say the EBC-IMF-EC officials aren't willing to count the staff who are being laid off at state broadcaster ERT.

Kathimerini explains:

Sources at the Administrative Reform Ministry told Kathimerini on Wednesday that “the basis for reaching an agreement is in place.”

One of the key problems is that the visiting inspectors refuse to recognize the 2,600 sackings at public broadcaster ERT as permanent dismissals. Until they are given detailed plans of how the new broadcaster will operate and how many employees it will take on, the officials will not accept that the government has carried out any firings.

So after all the anger and aggrevation over the sudden closure of ERT, it may not help Greece's case with the Troika after all...

9.33am BST

Short-selling ban reaches the City

Another reason for the bounceback on the Portuguese stock market is that Lisbon's financial regulator banned short-selling of four companies, including three banks whose shares all tumbled over 10% yesterday.

This prevents traders from selling shares they don't own, with a plan to buy them back cheaper after they've been routed.

And this morning, the UK's Financial Conduct Authority followed suit. It has prohibited anyone in the City from shorting Banco Comercial Portugues, Banco Espirito Santo or Sonae Industria.

The ban expires at midnight.....

Here's their announcement.

Updated at 9.58am BST

9.24am BST

Optimism abounds on Portugal's stock market - the PSI 20 is now up 3.5% on hopes that the country's leaders can resolve the crisis.

9.10am BST

Portugal's prime minister, Pedro Passos Coelho, is reported to have held "very constructive" talks last night with his junior coalition partner, Paulo Portas. That's via the Wall Street Journal's Patricia Kowsmann, in Lisbon.

A reminder about the political situation -- Passos Coelho's Social Democrats govern in a coalition with Portas's CDS-PP, or Conservative Popular Party. If CDS walk away then Passos Coelho could lose his majority. He could lead a minority government, but would be at risk of losing a confidence vote.

Passos Coelho had initially refused to accept Portas's resignation as foreign minister. And last night, CDS said that it didn't expect any oher ministers to also resign.

8.56am BST

Kit Juckes's early view:

Here's an early assessment of the situation today from Kit Juckes of Société Générale:

Portuguese political leaders are planning to hold talks to ease the country's political crisis, and even if they can't calm nerves completely, 10yr yields have already dropped back 30 basis points from last night's close. With the US on holiday, the ECB meeting take centre stage.

The UK MPC is also meeting. At some point, Mr Carney is going to want to shake things up in terms of post-meeting communication, but this week may be just a bit too soon.

8.48am BST

Shares recover too

Shares are also bouncing back on the Lisbon stock market. After yesterday's 5% tumble, the PSI 20 is up over 2% on hopes that the Portuguese government won't collapse.

Every share is up, led by banking stocks, which suffered badly yesterday.

Prime minister Pedro Passos Coelho insisted yesterday evening that he could ride out the storm. The news that his junior coalition partner hasn't jumped ship (yet, anyway), is fuelling optimism.

And here's the details:

• PSI 20: up 112 points at 5,348, +2.1%

• FTSE 100: up 56 points at 6285, +0.9%

• German DAX: up 72 points at 7901, + 0.9%

• French CAC: up 42 points at 3744, +1.15%

• Spanish IBEX up 51 points at 7807, +0.5%

• Italian FTSE MIB: up 103 points at 15376, + 0.68%

8.40am BST

Graph: Portuguese 10-year borrowing costs ease

And here's a graph of Portuguese 10-year bond yields this week, showing the sharp fall this morning back towards safer levels after yesterday's alarm:

Updated at 8.40am BST

8.31am BST

Portuguese bonds recover....

After an alarming day yesterday, the situation in Portugal appears to be easing.

Portuguese government bonds are recovering some value in early trading, after yesterday's sharp selloff. And the European stock markets are bouncing back too.

This follows the news last last night that the junior coalition partner (CDS) in the Portuguese government has pledged to play its part in holding the government together. Their party leader had sparked the crisis by dramatically quitting as foreign minister on Tuesday.

With the Portuguese president holding talks with party leaders today, there is hope that a deal can be hammered out to hold Pedro Passos Coelho's government together.

This has pushed up the value of Portugal's debt, driving down the value (effectively the interest rate) on its 10-year bonds to just 7.24%, from 7.5% last night. That's a sign of traders are less alarmed about the Lisbon situation.

Shares are also up across Europe -- details to follow.....

Updated at 8.33am BST

8.15am BST

Central banks in focus as BoE and ECB meet

Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the latest events in the eurozone, the financial crisis and the global economy.

It's Central Banks day in Europe, with the Bank of England and the European Central Bank's top officials gathering to set monetary policy in Britain and the eurozone.

And that means ECB president Mario Draghi facing the press this afternoon, at a time when the eurozone crisis is picking up pace again.

The political turmoil that broke out in Portugal this week is another reminder that, for all Draghi's talk of doing 'whatever it takes' to protect the euro, this remains a poitical crisis as well as an economic, financial and social one.

Analysts don't expect a cut in eurozone interest rates, but as ever, what Draghi says is almost as interesting as what he actually does. Carsten Brzeski of ING reckons the ECB president will urge the markets to stay calm, and pledge not to tighten monetary policy anytime soon:

In our view, the ECB remains in crisis mode. The eurozone economy is still lagging far behind the US economy and exit discussions at a moment in which the economy is showing that signs of a bottoming out are more than premature.

Draghi is also bound to field questions over issues such as whether the ECB is close to imposing negative interest rates on banks, and its promises of more support to help small firms borrow.

Draghi's views on Greece, where the government continues to meet with the Troika in an attempt to unlock its next €8bn bailout loans, could also be interesting...

At the Bank of England, it's the first time that new governor Mark Carney has voted on UK interest rates and quantitative easing. We're not expecting any fireworks – recent UK data has been quite upbeat – but you never know how the new man might shake things up....

I'll be watching both the Bank of England (decision at noon BST) and the European Central Bank (decision at 12.45pm, press conference at 1.30pm), along with the latest developments across the eurozone.
fields.trailText: FTSE 100 surges 3% and pound falls two cents against the US dollar as Bank of England and ECB surprise markets by saying interest rate rises are far away

webTitle: Help to Buy scheme seems doomed by a rigid planning system

fields.standfirst: Chancellor's scheme sees Taylor Wimpey share price rise, but is the housing crisis being addressed in the long term?
fields.body:
Taylor Wimpey's share price has risen by a fifth since the chancellor announced his Help to Buy scheme in March. No surprise there: investors in housebuilders know a good thing (for the companies) when they see it.

Taylor Wimpey completed its first Help to Buy transaction five weeks after the scheme was launched in April and it has now passed 1,000 reservations. The firm is even sounding sufficiently bullish about house prices to predict a modest write-back of impairment charges taken in previous years. Yes, life for housebuilders is looking up.

So, you might assume, a building boom is now in prospect. After all, fans of Help to Buy keep assuring us that, by stimulating demand for homes via government-subsidised mortgages, supply will surely follow.

No, it won't. Taylor Wimpey reckons it might build 10% more homes this year than last year. If that pattern is replicated across the industry, a grand total of about 115,000 new homes will be constructed this year. That is a far cry from the 200,000 a year that used to be deemed necessary to keep pace with underlying demand.

Are the housebuilders stalling by sitting on land? They say, reasonably convincingly, not. Taylor Wimpey, for example, says it is developing 99% of the plots where it has firm planning permission. The real culprit is said to be a rigid planning system that places an effective annual cap on construction at about 130,000 or 140,000 homes.

George Osborne's Help to Buy scheme may accelerate the construction of, say, 25,000 new homes but it will do nothing to address the long-term housing crisis.

Indeed, without serious planning reform – and there's no sign of that – it will make matters worse by pushing prices even further beyond first-time buyers.

webTitle: Piper Alpha anniversary: 'mockery' of safety by bullying, says whistleblower

fields.standfirst: North Sea oil and gas insider claims injuries still covered up by management and 'lost time accidents' manipulated by workers
fields.body:
A whistleblower has warned that a system of safety representatives set up to underpin the integrity of oil and gas platforms in the North Sea following the Piper Alpha explosion is being made a "mockery" owing to an atmosphere of offshore bullying by some managers.

The claims come just before tomorrow's formal 25th anniversary of the rig disaster – the world's deadliest offshore accident in in which 167 workers died.

The whistleblower, who has spent 20 years in the industry, claims some serious injuries continue to be covered up rather than reported while "lost time accidents" – a key industry safety measurement – can be manipulated by keeping injured employees on board a rig until it is time for their leave.

"Under Health and Safety Executive regulations a company is duty bound to look after workers by way of safety reps and their regular meetings. But it's a mockery. They don't often happen and top line supervisors risk losing bonuses if there are too many lost time incidents, so (injured) people are kept on board so they don't have to report it," said the offshore worker, who asked not to be named.

The whistleblower says there are many North Sea safety reps who never attend any safety sessions despite the HSE regulations calling for each group of workers to hold discussions every three months.

The offshore worker, whose identity is verified by the RMT union in Aberdeen, also said one of his colleagues had been re-elected as a safety rep by the workforce but his appointment had been overruled by the employer.

Jake Molloy, an Aberdeen-based organiser of the RMT, supports the claims made by the whistleblower, and estimates that the safety rep structure and industrial relations, in general, are either "poor or completely dysfunctional" on 40% of North Sea rigs or platforms.

He believes lost time injury statistics are "meaningless" and said BP's Deepwater Horizon accident in the Gulf of Mexico in 2010 showed the dangers of what happens when workers feel unable to challenge and halt drilling in dangerous situations.

"You can have the most technologically advanced rig on the planet like the Deepwater Horizon but it's now lying on the bottom of the sea with 11 dead … the danger of another Macondo is always real, especially on high-pressure wells in deep water off the (UK) west coast," he said.

Last month the HSE said the number of large gas and oil leaks from the UK's offshore installations rose in 2012 from three to nine, the highest in 14 years. Included in those figures was a leak that went on for almost two months on the Elgin platform operated by Total of France.

In late 2010 the same safety watchdog sent a report to rig operator, Transocean, in which staff alleged they had been bullied and harassed, something that was denied by the US company.

And in 2007 the HSE issued a report following a study showing that almost 60% of North Sea oil platforms had rusting or other problems that oil companies should have addressed.

But Oil & Gas UK, the employers' group, issued its latest annual health and safety report two week ago in which it reported a 48% reduction in the number of reportable oil and gas releases over the last three years and an all-time low last year in the incidence of "over-three day injuries", which it regards as key measures for good industry performance.

Sally Hatch, an Oil & Gas UK spokeswoman, said on Thursday eveningthat it did not recognise the picture painted by the whistleblower of bullying and intimidation.

"We are not aware of that scenario. Industry representatives are represented at the highest level with the RMT sitting on the Step Change in Safety partnership. Safety reps are trained by the oil and gas industry and are given all the tools and knowledge needed to represent their colleagues," she said.

"Reporting of offshore lost time injuries is very high. HSE inspectors periodically check first aid treatment records kept on the installation by the offshore medic as part of their planned inspection activities."

But she confirmed that only 91 of the 2,000 safety reps working across the North Sea had appeared at the Workforce Involvement Day at the Piper Alpha 25 event, which ran for three days and was a key event for discussing industry safety.

Frank Doran, whose first stint as an MP for Aberdeen coincided with the accident, said he believed there had been "huge improvements" in the general safety culture in the North Sea but he also warned there were still gaps in the system.

"There have been some pretty shocking figures on gas releases and some of contracting companies come under pressure from the big boys (larger groups) but the general trajectory is in the right direction. At the UK (oil and gas industry) safety awards the main speech was given by the general secretary of the Scottish TUC. That would have been unthinkable in the past."

webTitle: FTSE sees £48bn added after Carney and Draghi hint at further action to help economy

fields.standfirst: Leading shares recover all the loses made when Bernanke suggested US bond buying programme could end
fields.body:
Banks and miners led the way as leading shares recorded their best daily performance for 21 months.

Investors piled into riskier assets following unexpected comments from both the Bank of England and the European Central Bank suggesting that interest rates would remain low for some while and further stimulus to boost the global economy would be considered.

Their remarks saw the £48bn which was wiped off the UK's top companies when US Federal Reserve chairman Ben Bernanke hinted at an end to its QE programme two weeks ago, wiped back on again.

The FTSE 100 surged 191.8 points to finish at 6421.67, the largest daily rise since 27 September 2011. With Wall Street closed for the Independence Day holiday there was little to distract investors from the optimism which followed the central bank meetings. Even the eurozone crisis seemed calmer, with signs Portugal could avoid further elections, while the appointment of an interim president in Egypt was cautiously welcomed by markets after the recent turmoil. But the main attraction was undoubtedly the bank meetings. Brenda Kelly, senior market strategist at IG, said:

Little was expected from either the European Central Bank or Bank of England, yet much was delivered. While both interest rates remained unchanged, the central banks appeared to be at pains to appease investors' fears that tighter monetary policy was imminent. While we cannot suggest that this was a co-ordinated move from both central banks, there is a certain tendency to assume that this unprecedented rhetoric could be an attempt to temper the recent hawkish tones emanating from the US Federal Reserve. The jury is out on whether the gains seen today will be sustained; tomorrow's US payrolls release should help to clarify.

Anglo American added 56p to £12.63 while Rio Tinto rose 108.5p to 2757.5p.

Among the banks, Barclays bounced 11.95p to 292.7p while HSBC was 30.5p higher at 711.4p. Royal Bank of Scotland added 14.1p to 284.1p, helped by talk it would sell its equity derivatives business to help repair its balance sheet.

Housebuilders were in demand after a number of positive updates and an upbeat Halifax house price survey. Persimmon put on 53p to £12.66 while Redrow added 15.9p to 237.9p on good trading news. Taylor Wimpey climbed 6.85p to 103.8p after saying it expected to meet market expectations for the full year after trading well in the first half. Analyst Anthony Codling at Jefferies said:

If ever we need proof that the housing market is recovering, we have it now. Taylor Wimpey is anticipating a write back of some of its Net Realisable Value provision at the half year; whilst we expect the quantum to be small, the symbolism is quite the opposite. In our view, the group is expressing confidence that the market is now more likely to move up than down.

Marks & Spencer added 18.5p to 459.8p after a buy note from Panmure Gordon ahead of a trading update next week. Analyst Jean Roche said:

We are positive on Marks for four reasons: 1) strength in the food division; 2) potential for turnaround in the general merchandise division; 3) a growing, capital-light international business; and 4) a recent commitment to delivering improved returns to shareholders.

Online fashion retailer Asos jumped 5.5% after one of the City's more negative analysts on the stock changed his mind. In what amounted to a mea culpa, David Reynolds at Jefferies moved his rating from underperform to buy and his target price from £21.99 to a hefty £62. In the market Asos - which issued an upbeat trading statement in mid-June - added 228p to £43.55.

Elsewhere easyJet climbed 47p to £13.67 following an increase in June passenger numbers of 1.9%, while HSBC raised its target price from £14 to £15. The company is planning major expenditure on aircraft but HSBC said:

Capital expenditure and dividends are not incompatible: we model the company returning over £3bn in dividends from 2014 to 2020, whilst funding this proposed fleet plan.

Events in Egypt helped companies with operations there. Gold miner Centamin - which is in dispute with the authorities over the validity of its licence for its Sukari mine - climbed 4.6p to 35.75p. Analyst Maurice Mason at Peel Hunt said:

These developments clearly elevate the political uncertainty surrounding Centamin, and at this stage the implications for the ongoing court case is unknown. However, it should be remembered that Centamin's legal troubles started only since the current government was in power and its removal from office could ultimately turn out to be positive.

Meanwhile gases group BG, which has operations in the country, rose 32.5p to £11.38. In a note this week, analysts at RBC said concerns about the political risk in Egypt had been overplayed:

More than 50% of BG's production in Egypt goes to the domestic market, and in our view, popular discontent increases the importance to the government (Muslim Brotherhood or military) to maintain production.

But Schroders fell 19p to £22.36 despite a positive note from JP Morgan Cazenove which said:

Following completion of the acquisition of Cazenove Capital we resume coverage of Schroders with an overweight (price target 2281p) recommendation. In our view the company continues to offer a compelling investment despite the strength of share price performance seen in the year to date. webTitle: Car sales rise 13% in June alongside climb in house prices

fields.standfirst: Automobile industry enjoys 16th consecutive month of growth, with 215,000 cars sold in June and registrations up 10% in year
fields.body:
Car sales in June were up 13% on the same month last year, the 16th consecutive month of growth, while house prices rose in the same month at their fastest rate in three years, according to figures released on Thursday.

Just under 215,000 cars were sold last month, taking the total of new registrations for the year past the 1m mark to more than 1,163,000 – 10% higher than the same period last year, according to the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders.

Meanwhile house prices between April and June rose 3.7% on a year earlier to an average of £167,984, the biggest increase since August 2010, mortgage lender Halifax said. Values in June were 0.6% higher than May, the fifth consecutive month of rises.

Amid fears of a new property bubble, housebuilders and mortgage lenders called for more clarity on how the government will wind down its support scheme for struggling housebuyers which has boosted developers' profit forecasts.

Housebuilders such as Taylor Wimpey, Persimmon, Galliford Try and Redrow lifted profit forecasts this week.

"No industry should depend on those kind of measures long term … there needs to be an exit plan," Taylor Wimpey chief executive Pete Redfern said.

The support scheme is not due to start winding down until 2016, but the government has not provided details on how it will shut it down.

"Policymakers must be prepared to quickly pull the plug on the Help to Buy mortgage guarantee scheme at the first sign of any housing price bubble developing," said Howard Archer, IHS Global Insight's chief UK and European economist.

webTitle: Bank of England surprise statement sends markets up and sterling tumbling

fields.bodyText: Stock markets roared ahead and sterling tumbled after the Bank of England and European Central Bank took unprecedented steps to quash investor fears that they were preparing to reduce monetary stimulus. Under the chairmanship of new Bank of England governor, Mark Carney, the monetary policy committee issued an unexpected statement to indicate that despite a rise in inflation there was no need for the sharp rise in yields on government bonds, known as gilts. The rise in yields took place in the six weeks since the US Federal Reserve started to discuss reducing economic stimulus, rattling markets amid fears that other central bank would follow. And Mario Draghi, the head of the ECB, said the eurozone's central bank was taking unprecedented steps to give so-called forward guidance to reassure the markets that it had no plans to raise interest rates soon. The ECB, facing a new crisis in Portugal, had even discussed a rate cut, Draghi said. "The governing council expects the key ECB rates to remain at present or lower levels for an extended period of time," Draghi told a news conference. The unexpected statement from the MPC – chaired for the first time by Carney in his first week as Bank of England governor – pushed the FTSE 100 almost 200 points higher and drove sterling down against the dollar. Gilt yields also fell, after rising more than one percentage point since the start of May when the Fed first started discussing easing monetary policy, after the markets responded to the remarks by the MPC. The MPC's statement is a departure from the stance adopted by Carney's predecessor, Sir Mervyn King, who retired last week and who rarely issued statements immediately after rate-setting meetings. As expected the MPC left interest rates on hold at 0.5% – the historic low they have been at for more than four years – and quantitative easing (QE) unchanged at £375bn. While the decision not to embark on more QE had been expected and follows a string of upbeat data that has reinforced hopes that growth in the UK economy was stronger in the second quarter than the first, when gross domestic product increased by 0.3%. "At its meeting today, the committee noted that the incoming data over the past couple of months had been broadly consistent with the central outlook for output growth and inflation contained in the May [inflation] report. The significant upward movement in market interest rates would, however, weigh on that outlook; in the committee's view, the implied rise in the expected future path of Bank rate was not warranted by the recent developments in the domestic economy," the MPC said. The former MPC member, Andrew Sentance, tweeted: "Inflation is set to rise, and BoE statement pours cold water on rate rises. Pretty dismal signal from MPC to Britain's savers." Howard Archer, chief European and UK economist at IHS Global Insight, said: "With gilt yields having recently been sent significantly higher amid increased global financial market turmoil, the MPC likely felt it was a good move to make it clear at an early stage that any tightening in UK monetary policy is a considerable way off." Economists said more QE was also a possibility at the August policy meeting, by which point the MPC will have seen the Bank's latest forecasts for growth and inflation before its next quarterly inflation report. Since its last quarterly inflation report in May, the MPC said on Thursday that 12-month CPI inflation – a measure of consumer prices – had risen to 2.7% and could rise further before falling back. It also noted that interest rates being priced in by markets had risen sharply and asset prices had been volatile. "In the United Kingdom, there have been further signs that a recovery is in train, although it remains weak by historical standards and a degree of slack is expected to persist for some time," the MPC said. Interest rates have been at an all-time low of 0.5% since March 2009, the same month that the MPC made the unprecedented decision to introduce QE, its asset purchasing programming. James Knightley of ING said: "This is pretty aggressive stuff that has prompted a sharp move lower in sterling and suggests that Carney is very much in the dovish camp." Carney succeeded King as the Bank's governor on 1 July and how he voted at the meeting will not be known until 17 July. But it is now clearer that next month the MPC could start to provide guidance about the potential future path of interest rates, following in the footsteps of the Fed and marking a departure for the Bank. In the statement issued after the first meeting Carney chaired, the MPC said: "The latest remit letter to the MPC from the chancellor had requested that the committee provide an assessment, alongside its August inflation report, of the case for adopting some form of forward guidance, including the possible use of intermediate thresholds. This analysis would have an important bearing on the committee's policy discussions in August." The CBI's director of economics, Stephen Gifford, said: "Looking ahead, some form of forward guidance on interest rates remains a strong possibility. Although the MPC's scepticism will be hard to dispel, recent financial market volatility and today's statement by the Bank have strengthened the case for providing greater clarity around monetary policy, which businesses would welcome."

webTitle: Gulf Keystone appoints controversial businessmen Simon Murray as chairman

fields.standfirst: Former chair of Glencore and director of Sino Forest joins oil group with immediate effect
fields.body:
Gulf Keystone Petroleum has attempted to head off shareholder discontent by appointing a new chairman, although its choice of former French legionnaire Simon Murray is not without controversy.

The Kurdistan-focused oil company has come under pressure from investor M&G over its pay practices and corporate governance, and has already agreed to split the role of executive chairman held by Todd Kozel. Ahead of this month's annual meeting in Bermuda, it has announced 73 year old Murray would take the chair with immediate effect. He is also set to head the remuneration committee. Kozel, who will remain chief executive, said:

Simon's wealth of international business experience, particularly his experience in listing and chairing a FTSE 100 company, will be invaluable in leading our migration from Aim to the main market as we transition into the next phase of the company's development and become a significant oil producer in the Kurdistan region of Iraq.

Murray's experience includes senior roles at Jardine Matheson and Hutchison Whampoa, and he was chairman of Glencore when it listed, stepping down following its merger with Xstrata.

But he was also involved in Chinese group Sino Forest Corporation, which was accused of fraud and filed for bankruptcy protection in Canada almost a year ago.

At Glencore he ran into trouble for making sexist comments in an interview although he claimed his words had been taken out of context.

News of Murray's appointment seems to have pleased the market, with Gulf Keystone's shares 3.5p higher at 148.75p. Marc Kimsey, senior trader at Accendo Markets, said:

A defining moment in Gulf Keystone's history, the appointment of Simon Murray is a major coup. His CV is ideal - a track record in progressing major blue-chip energy companies and a 'black book' of City contacts. Shareholders should embrace this appointment as the company builds a boardroom fit for a full FTSE listing.

The company has also been holding an investor day, with Murray already prominent among the pictured directors.

It is still waiting for a court judgement over a legal challenge to its ownership of fields in northern Iraq.

webTitle: First British Airways A380 superjumbo arrives at Heathrow

fields.standfirst: Airbus says each A380 will save BA £100m in fuel costs over its lifetime and significantly cut noise disturbance
fields.body:
The first of a new generation of British Airways doubledecker superjumbos has arrived at Heathrow, bringing the promise of the quieter, fuel-efficient flying sought by passengers, airlines, and the airport's neighbours alike.

The 469-seat Airbus A380, the first to be owned by a UK airline, was signed over in a ceremony at the manufacturer's Toulouse airport base before departing for London.

Airbus claims that the giant planes, with an upper deck six feet wider than the Boeing 747s they will replace, will each save the airline £100m in fuel costs over their lifetimes. The fuel bill for one long-haul flight runs into six figures and the A380 is said to be 16% more efficient.

More significantly for those under the flightpath, the A380's "noise footprint" on landing at Heathrow – the area greatly affected by noise disturbance – is claimed to be a quarter of that of a 747.

Heathrow charges lower landing fees to quieter aircraft and is continuing to develop stands and taxiways to accommodate the A380s.

Matt Gorman, Heathrow's sustainability director, said the aircraft would contribute to noise reduction and that noise now affected fewer people around the airport than at any time since the 1970s, despite flight numbers having almost doubled.

Keith Williams, the chief executive of BA, told crew and passengers: "You're part of the future."

Both BA and Heathrow believe the aircraft will transform aviation – including the fraught debate over additional runways at London's hub airport. BA has ordered 12 A380s. Four other airlines already operate the planes out of Heathrow.

Williams said: "These aircraft are the start of a new era for British Airways. Over the next 15 months, we will take delivery of new aircraft at the rate of one a fortnight as we put ourselves at the forefront of modern aviation.

"The A380 is a fantastic aircraft and an excellent showpiece for British engineering. Our customers are going to love the space, light and comfort on board."

BA is unlikely to have secured the same discount on the $403m (£265m) list price obtained by the earliest adopters, but takes delivery after Airbus has resolved the problems of cracks in the wings that grounded several A380s in 2012.

Fabrice Brégier, the chief executive of Airbus, said it was a "very proud moment" and significant for the image of Airbus, marking the first longhaul aircraft the European manufacturer has supplied to a previously entirely Boeing-made BA longhaul fleet.

He said that BA, which has ordered 12 A380s as well as 18 A350s, the plane that made its first test flight last month, was among its top 10 customers but added, with a Gallic dash, that it was much higher "in our hearts" – a notable change from the once frosty relationship between Airbus and BA.

Brégier said that the constraints of Heathrow, where the limit on takeoffs and landings has been reached, meant that more airlines would be looking to the capacity offered by the superjumbo.

Airbus's chief operating officer, John Leahy, speaking aboard the flight from Toulouse, said that 40% of the A380 was British-made and that Airbus was sustaining 100,000 jobs in the wider supply chain. Around 4,500 people in Britain worked directly on the A380. BA has also chosen Trent-900 engines made by Rolls-Royce in Derby.

The flight touched down at Heathrow just after 10.30am, with the pilot, Captain James Basnett, telling passengers that the flight was making aviation history, adding: "Ladies and gentlemen, you have never seen a bigger smile on the face of a captain in your life."

The plane was met by 380 British Airways employees at a hangar in Heathrow.

BA's first Boeing 787 Dreamliners – carbon-fibre planes which are much smaller than the A380 but with a similar range and fuel efficiency – arrived at Heathrow last week, making BA the first airline in Europe to operate both of the pioneering planes.

The A380's first passenger flight will be to Los Angeles on 24 September.

webTitle: Asos adds 5% as broker reverses negative view

fields.standfirst: Jefferies issues buy note and puts £62 target on shares in online fashion retailer
fields.body:
Online fashion retailer Asos has jumped nearly 5% after one of the City's more negative analysts on the stock changed his mind.

In what amounts to a mea culpa, David Reynolds at Jefferies moved his rating from underperform to buy and his target price from £21.99 to a hefty £62. In the market Asos - which issued an upbeat trading statement in mid-June - has added 196p to £43.23. Reynolds said:

An ill-judged downgrade [in January is] reversed here as we evidence high-quality senior management, a massively disruptive business model, continuing brand momentum, positive key performance indicator trends and a true growth dynamic.
[In January] our thought was that gross margin compression and withdrawal of long-standing operating margin guidance would weigh. It didn't. Burgeoning revenue growth carried the story and the resultant outperformance made for a poor call. While we still have concerns regarding returns rates and the developing market opportunity, neither of these should materially impact the revenue growth profile, although there may be a margin impact.

webTitle: Marks & Spencer climbs ahead of trading update after buy note

fields.standfirst: Panmure Gordon positive on retailer, raising hopes of a new share buyback programme
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer shares have been under pressure since its full year results in May, and a trading update alongside its annual meeting next week will be keenly watched by investors.

There have been concerns about its UK store performance, especially in the general merchandise business. But the retailer is up 9.4p at 450.7p at the moment, helped by a buy note from Panmure Gordon. Analyst Jean Roche said:

Profit taking has sent the shares down 7.5% since its preliminary results on 21 May. Other than disappointing late May/early June weather, leading to a more promotional than expected backdrop, the investment case has not changed. We continue to rate the shares buy as we highlight a 4.2% 2014 estimated dividend yield and the prospect of a new share buyback programme.
We are positive on Marks for four reasons: 1) strength in the food division; 2) potential for turnaround in the general merchandise division; 3) a growing, capital-light international business; and 4) a recent commitment to delivering improved returns to shareholders. The next catalyst is the first quarter interim management statement on 9 July. Despite weak comps we are not advocating a positive surprise here: rather, we are reiterating our buy case, so that, should next Tuesday result in a buying opportunity, the buy case has been clearly articulated.

webTitle: FTSE 100 regains ground as Portuguese fears recede and Egypt appoints new president

fields.standfirst: Companies with interests in Egypt recover following ousting of president Morsi, with Centamin up 12%
fields.body:
Leading shares have recovered ground after Wednesday's falls, as the Portuguese political crisis eases and Egypt saw an interim president after a military coup.

Ahead of key interest rate and quantitative easing decisions from both the Bank of England and the European Central Bank, the FTSE 100 has gained 52.06 points to 6281.93. An overnight rise on Wall Street helped, but there will no guidance later from the US market which is closed for the Independence Day holiday. In Portugal there is growing optimism the country can avoid new elections, with reports of constructive talks between the coalition partners.

Elsewhere companies with interests in Egypt have been hit by the uncertainty surrounding the country's government, but the ousting of president Morsi has led to something of a rebound.

Gold miner Centamin - which is in dispute with the authorities over the validity of its licence for its Sukari mine - has jumped 3.85p to 35p. Analyst Maurice Mason at Peel Hunt said:

A military coup in Egypt has deposed the existing government and placed the head of the Supreme Court as interim leader. While it remains very early days, the indications are that the military's intention is not to maintain long-term control of the country. The head of the Egyptian Constitutional Court has been nominated as the interim president and both presidential and parliamentary elections are set to follow. Images from Tahrir Square appear to indicate popular support for the development.
These developments clearly elevate the political uncertainty surrounding Centamin, and at this stage the implications for the ongoing court case is unknown. However, it should be remembered that Centamin's legal troubles started only since the current government was in power and its removal from office could ultimately turn out to be positive. We maintain our buy recommendation, given the level of discount to our unrisked valuation, but would remind investors that the ultimate outcome is likely to be a binary one. We remain of the view that this binary outcome will be in Centamin's favour.

Meanwhile gases group BG, which has operations in the country, has added 24p to 112.9.5. In a note this week, analysts at RBC said concerns about the political risk in Egypt had been overplayed:

More than 50% of BG's production in Egypt goes to the domestic market, and in our view, popular discontent increases the importance to the government (Muslim Brotherhood or military) to maintain production.
In our view, the need to continue to supply suggests a... worst case scenario of 20% of E&P exposure, 50% of LNG exposure, totalling $360m net income.

Elsewhere easyJet has climbed 25p to £13.45 following an increase in June passenger numbers of 1.9%, while HSBC raised its target price from £14 to £15. The company is planning major expenditure on aircraft but HSBC said:

Capital expenditure and dividends are not incompatible: we model the company returning over £3bn in dividends from 2014 to 2020, whilst funding this proposed fleet plan.

Taylor Wimpey has climbed 3.45p to 100.4p after saying it expected to meet market expectations for the full year after trading well in the first half. There was also a positive update from Redrow, up 8.1p at 230.1p. On Taylor Wimpey, analyst Anthony Codling at Jefferies said:

If ever we need proof that the housing market is recovering, we have it now. Taylor Wimpey is anticipating a write back of some of its Net Realisable Value provision at the half year; whilst we expect the quantum to be small, the symbolism is quite the opposite. In our view, the group is expressing confidence that the market is now more likely to move up than down.

webTitle: Indian airline GoAir to hire female-only cabin crew in bid to cut fuel bill

fields.bodyText: Budget airlines are constantly on the lookout for ways to cut their fuel bills and India's GoAir is no different. Its latest idea is to hire female-only cabin crew, refusing applications from their heavier male counterparts in a bid to limit fuel burn. The low-cost airline has calculated that the move will save up to 30m rupees (£330,000) a year, because women 20kg lighter on average. Around 130, or 40%, of GoAir's existing crew members are male, and they will keep their jobs. But men will miss out in the future, as the airline presses ahead with ambitious expansion plans for 80 new aircraft by 2020 and around 2,000 cabin crew and pilots. It currently has a fleet of 15 aircraft. The chief executive, Giorgio De Roni, said the decision was driven by the rupee's sharp fall against the dollar over the past year. "The rupee's fall has hurt the industry badly. All major expenses – aircraft leasing, spare parts and fuel costs – are linked to the dollar," he told the Times of India. "We are looking at every possible way of cost-cutting to remain profitable." As operating costs rise, GoAir has taken other measures to reduce the weight on board its aircraft and limit fuel burn. Its in-flight magazines have been shrunk, and water tanks are not being filled to capacity. Aircraft are also using a single engine to taxi in order to save fuel. "Our new aircraft will have sharklets [wingtip devices] that will help in reducing fuel burn by 5%. From next year onwards, we will have sharklets installed in five of our existing planes, while the remaining 10 will be phased out to have a young fleet," De Roni said.

webTitle: Ofcom asks BT to slash cost of changing fibre-optic broadband provider

fields.standfirst: Regulator proposes reducing charges by as much as 80%, with new contracts reduced from a year to just one month
fields.body:
The cost of changing fibre-optic broadband providers could be slashed by as much as 80%, and new contracts reduced from a year to just one month, under proposals from the telecoms watchdog Ofcom.

Ofcom wants BT to cut its £50 wholesale charge for switching from one fibre-optic broadband provider to another to between £10 and £15, a saving which it hopes will be passed on to consumers. Providers such as BSkyB and TalkTalk rent BT's fibre network, rather than building their own, and have been asking for price controls and more flexibility.

The number of fibre customers has grown from 100,000 in 2010 to 1.4 million people today, and broadband providers are now actively marketing the superfast speeds to those frustrated with slower copper broadband services.

For customers who already have a fibre line, Ofcom is proposing the minimum wholesale contract when switching provider should be one month. Most fibre contracts tend to tie in consumers for 18 months. It is hoped shorter wholesale terms could lead to consumer deals of six months or less.

"The proposals are designed to promote competition in the superfast broadband market at the wholesale level," the regulator said. "These would be expected to flow through to consumer benefits in the form of lower retail prices and easier switching between superfast broadband providers."

To ensure BT continues to invest in building out its fibre network, which will reach two thirds of the country by spring next year, Ofcom has said it will not impose wholesale price regulation on the new technology until at least 2017.

Consumers waiting for a new line or a repair should also get a faster service from BT's Openreach engineers. Last year, when unusually wet weather caused delays, customers were left waiting an average of 27 days for their fibre-optic connection. The delay has now fallen back to nine days, but Ofcom said it would be monitoring Openreach to ensure it met agreed timeframes for installing new lines in a set percentage of cases.

The Ofcom proposals also revealed that BSkyB has formally asked BT to unbundle access to its fibre lines. Local loop unbundling of copper broadband lines, which saw rival broadband providers install their own equipment in BT exchanges, helped bring down prices for consumers and spur competition when it was introduced in the last decade.

Sky wants the freedom to offer different fibre products to BT, for example faster speeds, and wrote to the firm in January with a formal statement of requirements. The satellite broadcaster wants unbundling of street cabinets, of the lines running to them from local exchanges, and of the lines running from the cabinet to the home.

"We are constantly exploring ways in which we can customise our services, innovate further and encourage more of our customers to take our unlimited fibre products," a Sky spokesman said. "As such, we have submitted a set of requirements for an unbundled fibre-to-the-cabinet service to BT and the rest of industry."

The proposals were claimed as a victory by both BT and TalkTalk. "We are pleased that Ofcom is maintaining pricing freedom for Openreach's fibre products," a BT spokesman said. "BT has already accepted a long payback period for its fibre deployment and its fibre prices – which are among the lowest in Europe – reflect this."

Meanwhile, TalkTalk welcomed Ofcom's proposal that BT ensures there is a margin between what it charges rivals to rent its fibre and what it charges its own retail customers. TalkTalk is worried about "margin squeeze", where BT undercuts rivals by offering fibre to consumers for less than it charges wholesale. "TalkTalk has consistently maintained that fibre is too important for future economic growth to be monopolised by BT, and that for this reason access to fibre must be regulated," a spokeswoman said.

The regulator has asked for responses to its proposals by 25 September.
